title: Porter v. Labor Depot
description: In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the Appellant contends the Circuit Court erred: (1) as a matter of law in failing to issue more than a form order; and (2) as a matter of law in affirming the finding of the Appellate Panel that the claimant was NOT an employee of Labor Depot
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Isiah Porter, Appellant,
v.
Labor Depot, Employer, and Capital City Insurance Co., Carrier,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Reginald Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4212
Heard February 21, 2007 â€“ Filed March 5, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
E. Ros Huff, Jr., of Irmo, for Appellant.
Grady L. Beard, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Â In this workersâ€™ compensation action, the Appellate Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (SCWCC) found Claimant Isiah Porter (Porter) and Labor Depot did not have an employer-employee relationship.Â  Accordingly, the Appellate Panel did not have jurisdiction to award benefits. Â The circuit court affirmed the Decision and Order of the Appellate Panel.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Porter was injured on August 4, 2002, when he fell approximately twenty to thirty feet while allegedly working as a Labor Depot employee on the Strom Thurmond Fitness Center construction site in Columbia, South Carolina.Â  Emergency Medical Services (EMS) transported Porter to Richland Memorial Hospital where he was diagnosed with a dislocated hip and multiple fractures. Â Subsequently, Porter underwent surgery on his hip and cervical spine to repair his injuries.Â  As of his workersâ€™ compensation hearing date, Porter had not reached maximum medical improvement. 
The Richland Memorial Hospital emergency room and consultation reports noted Porter was positive for ethyl alcohol (ETOH) on the day of the accident.Â  Porter admitted to emergency room personnel he had been drinking earlier that day. Â He disclosed he usually drank about one and one half pints of liquor and one to two quarts of beer per day.Â  Porterâ€™s own testimony at the hearing confirmed he had a life-long history of drinking alcohol. Â He drank every day prior to August 4, 2002.Â  Additionally, Porterâ€™s medical history revealed reports of alcohol abuse on four previous occasions: September 7, 1993; November 27, 1997; March 8, 2002; and May 7, 2002.Â  
Porter was single and fifty-one years old at the time of the August 4, 2002 accident.Â  He attended school through the seventh grade, studied automobile painting and body work with Job Corps, and was employed primarily in janitorial and laborer jobs.Â  Porter has not worked in any capacity following the accident. 
Labor Depot denied Porterâ€™s claim for workersâ€™ compensation benefits, maintaining he was not a Labor Depot employee.[1]Â  Porter testified he completed an employment application and worked for Labor Depot for approximately six months prior to the accident.Â  His duties included cleaning up around the landfill and on construction sites.Â  He earned $300-$350 weekly.Â  On the day of the accident, a Sunday, Porter went to work at 3:00 p.m. and had been on the job for approximately forty-five minutes when the accident occurred.Â  He did not know the name of his supervisor or the name of the construction company on the job site that day, nor did he produce any documentation by way of check stubs or income tax returns as evidence of his employment with Labor Depot.Â  Robert Brown, allegedly a co-worker employed by Labor Depot, testified he worked with Porter on August 4, 2002 and witnessed the accident.Â  Brown did not present any additional evidence, other than his testimony, that he and Porter were employees of Labor Depot.Â  In addition, South Carolina Employment Security Commission (SCESC) records from 2002 showed no evidence of any employment relationship between Porter and Labor Depot. 
A Form 12A, Employerâ€™s First Report of Injury, dated October 30, 2002, was filed electronically with the SCWCC on Labor Depotâ€™s behalf.Â  An undated, handwritten First Report of Injury or Illness was prepared by Capital City Insurance (Carrier).Â  Porter filed a Form 50 requesting a hearing on January 29, 2004 and an Amended Form 50 on August 2, 2004.Â  The hearing before the single commissioner on September 21, 2004, resulted in the following dispositive finding:

Claimant failed to meet his burden of proving, by the greater weight of evidence, that he was an employee of defendant, Labor Depot. Â Therefore, I find that the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission does not have jurisdiction to decide the matter.Â  This Finding is based on the testimony of the witnesses, including the claimant, the exhibits, or lack thereof, presented by each party, and the discretion of the Hearing Commissioner as the fact finder in this case to properly weigh the evidence and judge witness credibility.Â  

The Decision and Order of the Appellate Panel sustained and adopted the single commissionerâ€™s Order in its entirety.Â  On appeal, the circuit court issued a Form 4 Order stating:Â  â€œDecision of the Commission is affirmed.â€
ISSUES

(1) Did the circuit court err as a matter of law in issuing a form order without making findings of fact or conclusions of law for review by the appellate court?
(2) Did the circuit court err as a matter of law in affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s Decision and Order that Porter was not an employee of Labor Depot? 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Judicial review of a Workersâ€™ Compensation decision is governed by the substantial evidence rule of the Administrative Procedures Act. Baxter v. Martin Bros., Inc., 368 S.C. 510, 513, 630 S.E.2d 42, 43 (2006); Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 438 (2000).Â  However, if the factual issue before the Commission involves a jurisdictional question, this courtâ€™s review is governed by the preponderance of evidence standard. Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594, 564 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2002); Vines v. Champion Bldg. Prods., 315 S.C. 13, 431 S.E.2d 585 (1993); Lake v. Reeder Constr. Co., 330 S.C. 242, 498 S.E.2d 650 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Consequently, our review is not bound by the Commissionâ€™s findings of fact on Â jurisdiction. Â Id.Â  A reviewing court has both the power and duty to review the entire record, find jurisdictional facts without regard to conclusions of the Commission on the issue, and decide the jurisdictional question in accord with the preponderance of evidence. Â Canady v. Charleston County Sch. Dist., 265 S.C. 21, 25, 216 S.E.2d 755, 757 (1975); see also Kirksey v. Assurance Tire Co., 314 S.C. 43, 443 S.E.2d 803 (1994) (holding this court can find facts in accordance with the preponderance of evidence when determining a jurisdictional question in a Workersâ€™ Compensation case); Sanders v. Litchfield Country Club, 297 S.C. 339, 377 S.E.2d 111 (Ct. App. 1989) (deciding where a jurisdictional issue is raised, this court must review record and make its own determination whether the preponderance of evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s factual findings bearing on that issue).
The existence of the employer-employee relationship is a jurisdictional question. Â Nelson, 349 S.C. at 594, 564 S.E.2d at 112; South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commâ€™n v. Ray Covington Realtors, Inc., 318 S.C. 546, 459 S.E.2d 302 (1995); Edens v. Bellini, 359 S.C. 433, 597 S.E.2d 863 (Ct. App. 2004); see also Lake, 330 S.C. at 247, 498 S.E.2d at 653 (holding existence of employer-employee relationship is jurisdictional question; injured workerâ€™s employment status, as it affects jurisdiction, is matter of law for decision by court and includes findings of fact that relate to jurisdiction). Â 
The question of subject matter jurisdiction is a question of law. Â Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 528 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2000); Roper Hosp. v. Clemons, 326 S.C. 534, 484 S.E.2d 598 (Ct. App. 1997)).Â  On appeal from the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, this court may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Act No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387, eff. July 1, 2006); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The appellant bears the burden of showing that the circuit courtâ€™s decision is against the preponderance of evidence.Â  Gray, 339 S.C. at 182, 528 S.E.2d at 440 (citing Â Lake, 330 S.C. at 246, 498 S.E.2d at 653).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Circuit Judgeâ€™s Form Order
Porter contends the circuit court erred in failing to make specific findings of fact and conclusions of law on the issue of whether an employer-employee relationship between Porter and Labor Depot existed. Â We disagree.Â  
Advancing his contention, Porter relies on Bowen v. Lee Process Sys. Co., 342 S.C. 232, 536 S.E.2d 86 (Ct. App. 2000), wherein this court remanded the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment for an order more specifically identifying the grounds for its ruling.Â  In Bowen, we were unable to discern from the trial courtâ€™s decision â€œwhether the court found Defendants owed no duty to [Plaintiff], whether they owed a duty to [Plaintiff] and breached it, or whether they were negligent, but not grossly negligent.â€ Â Bowen, 342 S C. at 240, 536 S.E.2d at 90. Â In order to review the issue adequately, we required the trial court to articulate its rationale and legal analysis more precisely. Â Similarly, in B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 271, 603 S.E.2d 629, 631-32 (Ct. App. 2004), we instructed: 

On appeal from the grant of summary judgment, an appellate court must determine whether the trial courtâ€™s stated grounds for its decision are supported by the record. Â It is our duty to undertake a thorough and meaningful review of the trial courtâ€™s order and the entire record on appeal. Â Where, as here, the trial court fails to articulate the reasons for its action on the record or enter a written order outlining its rationale, we simply cannot perform our designated function.

However, not all situations require a detailed order, and the trial courtâ€™s form order may be sufficient if the appellate court can ascertain the basis for the trial courtâ€™s ruling from the record on appeal. Â Clark v. S.C. Â Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 353 S.C. 291, 578 S.E.2d 16 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œ[T]here is no blanket requirement that the trial court set forth a separate explanation on all of its rulings.â€ Â Id. at 312, 578 S.E.2d at 26; see also Bailey v. Segars, 346 S.C. 359, 550 S.E.2d 910 (Ct. App. 2001) cert. dismissed as improvidently granted 354 S.C. 57, 579 S.E.2d 605 (2003) (holding a form order stating only that the appellantâ€™s post-trial motions for JNOV and new trial were denied was, together with the record of the proceedings, adequate to enable appellate review).
It is well settled that â€œ[t]he findings of fact of an administrative body must be sufficiently detailed to enable the reviewing court to determine whether the findings are supported by the evidence and whether the law has been properly applied to those findings.â€ Â Heater of Seabrook, Inc. v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n of S.C., 332 S.C. 20, 26, 503 S.E.2d 739, 742 (1998).Â  Furthermore, courts reviewing the decisions of administrative agencies may look to written documents as well as records of proceedings as sufficient formats for final decisions.Â 
Austin v. Bd. of Zoning Appeals, 362 S.C. 29, 34, 606 S.E.2d 209, 212 (Ct. App. 2004). Â 
Here, the circuit court placed its imprimatur on the Appellate Panelâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law by affirming the Panelâ€™s decision.Â  Accordingly, the Appellate Panelâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law, as incorporated by reference to the single commissionerâ€™s order, became those of the circuit court.Â  The order encapsulated the single commissionerâ€™s Â Â ruling: 
FINDINGS OF FACT

The undersigned has carefully considered and reviewed all of the evidence presented by both parties in this claim, including the Claimantâ€™s testimony and the APA Submissions.Â  From this evidence it is found as a fact that:
1.  The claimant was not an employee of The Labor Depot, and the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, therefore, lacks jurisdiction over this alleged claim.
2.  The claimant alleges that he injured his back, neck, right shoulder, and right hip in a work-related accident, when he fell approximately 20 feet at a job site on August 4, 2002.Â  This Finding is based on the Form 50 dated August 2, 2004. 
3.  The South Carolina Employment Security Commission records from 2002 show no entry for any employment relationship between claimant and defendant, The Labor Depot.Â  In fact, they show claimant did not receive any wages during this time.Â  This Finding is based on defendantâ€™s APAâ€™s # 38-48.
4.  Claimant could not name his supervisor or the construction company for which he allegedly performed the work.Â  Claimant also failed to remember when he first began his employment with defendant, The Labor Depot.Â  This Finding is based on the testimony of the claimant.
5.  Although claimant stated that he had been paid by check, he produced no check stubs, tax records or other evidence of his employment.Â  This Finding is based on the claimantâ€™s testimony as well as the exhibits or lack thereof submitted by claimant. 
6.  Claimant failed to meet his burden of proving, by the greater weight of the evidence, that he was an employee of defendant, The Labor Depot.Â  Therefore, I find that the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission does not have jurisdiction to decide the matter.Â  This Finding is based on the testimony of the witnesses, including the claimant, the exhibits or lack thereof, presented by each party, and the discretion of the Hearing Commissioner as the fact finder in this case to properly weigh the evidence and judge witness credibility.
7.  Even if claimant were The Labor Depotâ€™s employee, it should be noted that medical records contradict claimantâ€™s testimony that he did not drink any alcohol on August 4, 2002; and also contradict claimantâ€™s testimony about his drinking habits generally.Â  Therefore, I find that claimant was not credible (e.g., claimant testified at the time of the accident that he only drank on weekends; however, notes from EMS and the Emergency Room both state that he was positive for ETOH, and claimant told various health care providers that he drank everyday).Â  This Finding is based on the claimantâ€™s testimony as well as the medical evidence in the record of the case. 
8.  Because I find that claimant did not prove that he was an employee of The Labor Depot, I do not reach the issue of whether claimant was intoxicated and whether that intoxication was the proximate cause of the accident.Â  This Finding is based on the testimony of the witnesses, including the claimant, and the discretion of the Hearing Commissioner as the fact finder in this case to properly weigh the evidence and rule in the case. 
9.  Claimantâ€™s request for benefits under the Act is denied.Â  This Finding is based upon all evidence in this case. 

CONCLUSIONS OF LAW

Based on the foregoing Findings of Fact and is [sic] provided in the South Carolina Code of Law Â§ 42-17-40, as determination of this Commissioner that:
1.  Under Â§ 42-1-130, the claimant was not a covered employee at the time in question; therefore, the SCWCC has no jurisdiction over this alleged claim.
2.  Under Â§ 42-1-130, Â§ 42-1-160, Â§ 42-9-10 and Â§ 42-15-60, the claimant has failed to carry the burden of proving that he was an employee of the Labor Depot, and that he is entitled to benefits under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act for an accident sustained in the course of his employment with The Labor Depot on August 4, 2002.Â  The claimantâ€™s claim for benefits . . . is, therefore, denied. Â Â Â Â Â Â  

The single commissionerâ€™s detailed findings were sufficient to allow the reviewing court to determine whether those findings were supported by the evidence and whether the law was properly applied to those findings.Â  The Appellate Panelâ€™s Decision and Order, together with the record of the proceedings, adequately enabled the reviewing court to perform its designated duty.Â  We find no error with regard to the format of the circuit courtâ€™s order. 
II. Â Existence of Employer-Employee Relationship
Porter argues the greater weight of the evidence proves he had an employer-employee relationship with Labor Depot.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â  
Coverage under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act depends on the existence of an employment relationship. Â Edens v. Bellini, 359 S.C. 433, 439, 597 S.E.2d 863, 866 (Ct. App. 2004) (citingÂ  Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 564 S.E.2d 110 (2002); McDowell v. Stilley Plywood Co., 210 S.C. 173, 41 S.E.2d 872 (1947); Hancock v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 355 S.C. 168, 584 S.E.2d 398 (Ct. App. 2003)); see also Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 184, 528 S.E.2d 435, 441 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œBefore provisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act can apply, an employer-employee relationship must exist; this is an initial fact to be established.â€).Â  Workersâ€™ compensation awards are authorized only if an employer-employee relationship exists at the time of the injury. Â Nelson, 349 S.C. at 594, 564 S.E.2d at 112 (citing Â Dawkins v. Jordan, 341 S.C. 434, 534 S.E.2d 700 (2000)).Â  
Section 42-1-130 of the South Carolina Code of Laws defines â€œemployeeâ€ as

every person engaged in an employment under any appointment, contract of hire, or apprenticeship, expressed or implied, oral or written, including aliens and also including minors, whether lawfully or unlawfully employed, but excludes a person whose employment is both casual and not in the course of the trade, business, profession, or occupation of his employer; 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-130 (Supp. 2006).
Workersâ€™ compensation statutes are construed liberally in favor of coverage, and South Carolinaâ€™s policy is to resolve jurisdictional doubts in favor of the inclusion of employees within workersâ€™ compensation coverage. Â Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 343 S.C. 102, 538 S.E.2d 276 (Ct. App. 2000) affâ€™d 349 S.C. 589, 564 S.E.2d 110 (2002) (citing Mauldin v. Dyna-Color/Jack Rabbit, 308 S.C. 18, 416 S.E.2d 639 (1992); Oâ€™Briant v. Daniel Constr. Co., 279 S.C. 254, 305 S.E.2d 241 (1983); Horton v. Baruch, 217 S.C. 48, 59 S.E.2d 545 (1950); Spivey v. D.G. Constr. Co., 321 S.C. 19, 467 S.E.2d 117 (Ct. App. 1996); McLeod v. Piggly Wiggly Carolina Co., 280 S.C. 466, 313 S.E.2d 38 (Ct. App. 1984)).
The fundamental test of the employment relationship is the right of the employer to control the details of the employeeâ€™s work. Nelson, 343 S.C. at 110, 538 S.E.2d at 280 (citing Â Gray, 339 S.C. at 184-85, 528 S.E.2d at 441).Â  â€œIt is not the actual control then exercised, but whether there exists the right and authority to control and direct the particular work or undertaking, as to the manner or means of its accomplishment.â€Â  Young v. Warr, 252 S.C. 179, 189, 165 S.E.2d 797, 802 (1969); Gray, 339 S.C. at 184-85, 528 S.E.2d at 441.Â  â€œThere are four elements which determine the right of control: 1) direct evidence of the right or exercise of control; 2) furnishing of equipment; 3) right to fire; and 4) method of payment.â€Â  Fuller v. Blanchard, 358 S.C. 536, 542-43, 595 S.E.2d 831, 834 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Nelson, 349 S.C. at 594, 564 S.E.2d at 113.
While the appellate court may take its own view of the preponderance of evidence on the existence of an employer-employee relationship, the final determination of witness credibility is usually reserved to the Appellate Panel. Â See Dawkins v. Jordan, 341 S.C. 434, 441, 534 S.E.2d 700, 704 (2000) (citing Ford v. Allied Chem. Corp., 252 S.C. 561, 167 S.E.2d 564 (1969)).
In support of his argument that the greater weight of evidence supports an employer-employee relationship, Porter offered his own testimony.Â  He averred he completed an employment application, worked for Labor Depot for approximately six months prior to his accident, and received paychecks from Labor Depot in the amount of $300-$350 weekly.Â  Porter claims he reported to work on Sunday, August 4, 2002 at 3:00 oâ€™clock in the afternoon and was instructed by the â€œboss manâ€ to dismantle scaffolding at the Strom Thurmond Fitness Center construction site.Â  About forty-five minutes after he had been on the site, he fell and sustained injuries. Â Porter submits that Labor Depot had the right of control over his employment because the â€œboss manâ€ directed his work activities and Labor Depot told him when and where to work. Â Â Â 
Porterâ€™s testimony lacks credibility.Â  He professed to be employed with Labor Depot for approximately six months prior to August 4, 2002.Â  Yet SCESC records showed no evidence of that employment.Â  Moreover, SCESC records indicated Porter drew unemployment compensation from November, 2001, until June 9, 2002.Â  In response to questioning about how he obtained unemployment compensation and worked for Labor Depot at the same time, Porter responded:

  
    
      A:  
       At that time of year you isnâ€™t employed every month.Â  Â  Sometimes they donâ€™t send you out every morning, every Â Â  day.Â  You donâ€™t get out every day.Â  You know you get Â Â Â Â Â Â  about one day a week or something like that.
        
        
    
    
      Q:  
       I appreciate that, Mr. Porter, but according to these records Â  you were filing for and pursuing unemployment from July of 2001 until June of 2002.
        
        
    
    
      A:
       Yeah.
        
        
    
    
      Q: 
       My question to you is if you were working for my client Â Â Â Â Â Â  during that period of time how were you filing for Â Â Â Â  unemployment every single week?
        
        
    
    
      A:
       I wasnâ€™t making no money.Â  I would probably get out about Â Â  one day a week.Â 
    
  

In addition, Porterâ€™s testimony concerning his alcohol consumption, both on the day of the accident and in general, conflicted with medical evidence provided in EMS reports, emergency room records, and prior medical histories. Â Significantly, Porter did not even recall previous injuries that apparently led to his disclosure of alcohol abuse to medical personnel. Â 
Porter did not remember the name of the â€œboss manâ€ who supervised the work site on the day of the accident, nor could he name the construction company involved in the project.Â  Robert Brown testified he worked for Labor Depot along with Porter on August 4, 2002, and witnessed the accident.Â  However, like Porter, Brown was unable to provide the name of the supervisor or the construction company.Â  Neither Porter nor Brown offered any documentary evidence of employment with Labor Depot in the form of wage receipts, check stubs, copies of completed applications, W-2 forms, or copies of income tax returns.Â  Concomitantly, we note the absence of personnel records and testimony from Labor Depot that Porter could have subpoenaed to support his position.Â  
Porter invests the Form 12A Employerâ€™s First Report of Injury tendered on Labor Depotâ€™s behalf with more significance than it merits, suggesting that, as a declaration against interest, it was sufficient to establish an employment relationship between Porter and Labor Depot.Â  Porter urges the Form 12A would not have been filed had he not been employed by Labor Depot.[2]Â  Regulation 67-411 of the South Carolina Code Ann. (2006) requires, in pertinent part, that:

A. Each employer shall keep a record of all injuries, fatal or otherwise, received by its employees in the course of their employment. . . .
B. Â Employerâ€™s Responsibilities
(1) The employer shall make a record of all work-related injuries reported by its employees on the Form 12A and retain the record for a period of two years.

S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-411 (2006).
To infer, as Porter urges, that the filed Form 12A represents Labor Depotâ€™s record keeping of an employeeâ€™s injuries strains credulity.Â  On September 26, 2002, the SCWCC Claims Director notified the Carrier that a workersâ€™ compensation claim had been filed against its insured, Labor Depot.Â  The Form 12A in the record on appeal, dated October 30, 2002, was filed by the Carrier, apparently in response to the Claims Directorâ€™s request for the completed form.Â  There is no evidence that anyone reported Porterâ€™s injury directly to Labor Depot.Â  There is evidence, however, that a letter of representation from Porterâ€™s former counsel accompanied the Claims Directorâ€™s request for the Form 12A.Â  Dated September 12, 2002, that letter to the SCWCC, establishing a claim on Porterâ€™s behalf, contained all of the data needed to complete the Form 12A.Â  The more tenable view of what the Form 12A represents in this case is that it was the Carrierâ€™s response to the SCWCCâ€™s notice of a filed claim rather than a representation of Labor Depotâ€™s record keeping of an employeeâ€™s injury. 
While we are mindful that jurisdictional doubts are generally to be resolved in favor of coverage, more than doubt taints Porterâ€™s claim that he was employed by Labor Depot.Â  Considering the evidentiary record as a whole, including our own view of the testimony, medical reports, and exhibits or lack thereof, we conclude Porter failed to demonstrate by a preponderance of evidence that an employer-employee relationship with Labor Depot existed.Â  
CONCLUSION
We discern no error as a matter of law in the circuit courtâ€™s form order affirming the decision of the Appellate Panel.Â  In addition, we hold Porter failed to prove by the preponderance of evidence that an employment relationship existed.Â  Lucidly, as a matter of law, Porterâ€™s claim does not fall within the jurisdiction of the South Carolina Workerâ€™s Compensation Commission.Â  
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
 KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  Labor Depot asserted intoxication, among other affirmative defenses, in the event the Appellate Panel determined an employer-employee relationship existed.Â  In concluding that no such relationship existed, the Panel was without jurisdiction to determine whether intoxication was the proximate cause of the accident.Â  Accordingly, the intoxication defense is not before this court for review. 
[2]  Two Form 12As appear in the record.Â  One Form 12A is handwritten, undated, and apparently prepared by the Carrier.Â  The second Form 12A, dated October 30, 2002 was submitted electronically by the Carrier, apparently through Southeastern Claims Services.Â  At the September 2004 hearing, the single commissioner opined: â€œI think itâ€™s clear that an insurance company filled this [Form 12A] out and not the employer.â€

title: State v. Edwards
description: In this criminal case the court affirms the trial court's rulings denying a mistrial and admitting evidence of prior bad acts and threats made by the defendant against the victim/witness.
text:
State v. Edwards


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Daniel Edwards, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4213
Heard February 7, 2007- Filed March 12, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Tara Shurling, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; Solicitor John R. Justice, of Chester, for Respondent. 
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Daniel Edwards, Jr. appeals his convictions for three counts of criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The victimâ€™s parents divorced when she was five or six years old. Â She lived with her father until she was ten but had regular visitation with her mother and her motherâ€™s husband, the defendant, Daniel Edwards, Jr.Â  When the victim was ten years old, she resumed living with her mother and Edwards. Â The victimâ€™s relationship with Edwards prior to this time was â€œa good one, like father/daughter.â€ Â She stated they would go hunting and fishing together and she felt comfortable with him â€œuntil things started to happen.â€Â  It was after the victim moved in with her mother and Edwards that the sexual assaults began.Â  
Edwards was indicted on three counts of second-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor, and his case was tried November 15-17, 2004.Â  The victim was sixteen at the time of trial.
The trial began with the victimâ€™s testimony. Â The jury was excused to allow the solicitor to proffer evidence regarding prior instances of sexual abuse toward the victim by Edwards.Â  The victim testified that the sexual abuse began when she, her mother, and Edwards lived on Golf Course Road in October, 1999. Â She stated she remembered the approximate date because it was â€œa couple of days after he got out of jail for my sister.â€Â  She stated that Edwards started by sitting by her bed and touching her breasts and â€œdown below.â€Â  Edwards continued the abuse a few weeks later when they moved to Nickey Road.Â  When her mother was at work in the evenings, he would sit by her bed and touch and rub her.Â  The victim testified Edwards had sexual intercourse with her four times, three of which were on Nickey Road, as well as having her look at pornographic magazines and watch pornographic tapes. Â The victim testified that on August 25, 2000, her mother left for work, and Edwards took her into his bedroom, took her clothes off, and began touching her breasts.Â  She said when he stepped out of the bedroom for a minute, she slipped out the back door and was able to call for help. Â 
Edwards argued the evidence was inadmissible, because there was no common scheme pursuant to Lyle,[1] and because it was more prejudicial than probative. The trial judge disagreed and permitted the testimony. Â Counsel noted his continuing objection to the admission of the evidence.Â  
In the course of her testimony, the solicitor asked the victim why she had complied with the things Edwards asked her to do.Â  She answered, â€œbecause I have already heard that heâ€™s been hitting my mother.â€Â  Edwards objected and moved for a mistrial, arguing he did not believe there was a curative instruction that could sufficiently remove the prejudice created by the victimâ€™s statement.Â  The trial judge denied the motion for a mistrial and gave a curative instruction when the jury returned to the courtroom. 
The victimâ€™s mother also testified in the case regarding threats made against the victim by Edwards.Â  The record indicates that though they were then estranged, the victimâ€™s mother stayed with Edwards for three years after the charges were brought and was still in communication with him up to the time of the trial.Â  The victimâ€™s mother testified that Edwards told her to tell the victim that she should not show up in court â€œbecause he had a hit out on her, that she wouldnâ€™t make it through the courtroom doors.â€Â  The victimâ€™s mother also testified that Edwards said if he was convicted he would kill the victim when he got out of jail.Â  The trial judge allowed this testimony finding that Edwardsâ€™ statements could be construed as an admission of guilt and a threat to punish the witness should the jury find him guilty.Â  
At the conclusion of the trial, the jury found Edwards guilty of all three charges.Â  Edwards raises three issues on appeal, alleging the trial judge erred in (1) admitting testimony regarding prior sexual conduct between the victim and Edwards, (2) denying Edwardsâ€™ motion for mistrial after the victim testified that Edwards had hit the victimâ€™s mother, and (3) in admitting testimony regarding threats made against the victim if she testified in court. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  See State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 344, 349, 592 S.E.2d 344, 347 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œOn appeal from a suppression hearing, this court is bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings if any evidence supports the findings.â€).Â  â€œThis same standard of review applies to preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.â€Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â  The admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002).Â  A courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error, which results in prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 353, 543 S.E.2d 586, 591 (Ct. App. 2001), overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Admission of Prior Bad Acts 
Edwards contends the trial judge erred in admitting evidence of prior acts of sexual misconduct, arguing the evidence did not constitute a common scheme or plan under Mathis and Lyle.Â  We disagree.
The trial judge determined that based largely on State v. Mathis,[2] he would permit â€œsome degree of testimonyâ€ relating to Edwardsâ€™ alleged prior misconduct and that the probative value of the testimony outweighed the prejudice to Edwards under Rule 403 of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence. Â 
Generally, South Carolina law precludes evidence of prior crimes or other bad acts to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt for the crime charged.Â  State v. Pagan, 369 S.C. 201, 211, 631 S.E.2d 262, 267 (2006); State v. Mathis, 359 S.C. 450, 462, 597 S.E.2d 872, 878 (Ct. App. 2004); see also State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 135, 536 S.E.2d 679, 682 (2000) (finding that evidence of prior crimes or bad acts is inadmissible to prove bad character of defendant or that he acted in conformity therewith). Â Such evidence is admissible, however, when it tends to establish â€œa common scheme or plan embracing the commission of two or more crimes so related to each other that proof of one tends to establish the others.â€Â  State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 416, 118 S.E. 803, 807 (1923); see also Rule 404(b),
SCRE. 
The common scheme or plan exception is commonly applied in cases of sexual assault where conduct both before and after the acts charged is held admissible to show â€œcontinued illicit intercourse between the same parties.â€Â  Mathis, 359 S.C. at 879, 597 S.E.2d at 463 (citing State v. Weaverling, 377 S.C. 460, 469, 523 S.E.2d 787, 791 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  In Mathis, the court admitted evidence of three earlier assaults on the victim where â€œall [three were] attempted in the same manner and under similar circumstances.â€Â 
Id. at 879, 597 S.E.2d at 464.Â  â€œOverall, the three prior incidents of sexual misconduct by Mathis show the same
illicit conduct with the victim over the course of the nine months prior to [the date of the charged incident].â€Â  Id. at 880, 597 S.E.2d at 464-65.Â  
In the present case, we find the admission of evidence of prior bad acts is consistent with the exceptions found in Lyle and particularly in Mathis. Â Edwardsâ€™ prior acts occurred over an approximately ten-month span with the same victim and always when the victimâ€™s mother was at work.Â  The conduct began with inappropriate touching, the removal of the victimâ€™s clothes, and finally escalated to sexual intercourse.Â  Edwards also told the victim to â€œkeep this a secret between me and youâ€ and that he would â€œbuy [her] thingsâ€ to keep her quiet. Â These acts constitute a â€œcontinued illicit intercourse between the same parties.â€Â  See Mathis, 359 S.C. at 879, 597 S.E.2d at 463.Â  Additionally, we agree with the trial judge that the probative value of the alleged prior bad acts outweighs the prejudicial effect of admitting the evidence.Â  
II.  Denial of Motion for Mistrial
Edwards argues the trial judge erred in denying his motion for a mistrial where the jury improperly heard evidence that Edwards had hit his wife.Â  We disagree.
The decision to grant or deny a mistrial is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be overturned on appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  State v. Stanley, 365 S.C. 24, 33, 615 S.E.2d 455, 460 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Rowlands, 343 S.C. 454, 458, 539 S.E.2d 717, 719 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Granting of a mistrial is a serious and extreme measure which should only be taken when the prejudice can be removed no other way.Â  Stanley, 365 S.C. at 34, 615 S.E.2d at 460.Â  â€œGenerally, a curative instruction to disregard the testimony is deemed to have cured any alleged error.â€Â  State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 658, 623 S.E.2d 122, 129 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 226, 522 S.E.2d 845, 850 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
The trial judge found the victimâ€™s statement that she â€œheard he [Edwards] had been hitting [her] motherâ€ was â€œa classic non-hearsay statement because itâ€™s not offered for the truth of the matter asserted.â€Â  We agree.Â  The victimâ€™s statement went to her state of mind and was not offered to establish that Edwards had actually ever hit her mother.Â  It was offered to explain why the victim behaved as she did.[3]Â  Consequently, the statement was admissible.
Furthermore, we find that any prejudice to Edwards was cured by the judgeâ€™s curative instruction.Â  The jury was instructed to â€œdisregard the last statement given by [the] witness in response to a question that was asked of her,â€ and the trial resumed. Â The instruction was simple and refrained from reiterating or emphasizing the statement as much as possible.Â  Even though the trial judge noted Edwardâ€™s continuing objection, we find the instruction cured any alleged error. Â We can discern no abuse of discretion in the judgeâ€™s denial of Edwardsâ€™ motion for mistrial.
III.  Admission of Threats Against a Witness
Edwards argues the trial judge erred in admitting evidence of alleged threats against the victim.Â  We disagree. 
This appears to be a novel issue to South Carolina, as we have been unable to locate any cases affirming the introduction of such threats into evidence.Â  There are cases, however, addressing the subject but disallowing the evidence, primarily because the threats could not be directly attributed to the defendant.Â  The first such case was State v. Rogers, 96 S.C. 350, 80 S.E. 620 (1914), in which the trial court admitted into evidence an unsigned letter threatening one of the stateâ€™s witnesses.Â  The defendantâ€™s conviction was reversed, and in doing so the court stated, 

[h]is Honor should not have admitted in evidence the letter complained of in the first exception . . . without connecting the defendant in some manner with it.Â  It would have been better to require the State then and there after it was admitted to connect the defendant with it, and upon failure to do so to have ruled it out. Â 

Id. at 352, 805 S.E.2d at 621.Â  Similarly, in Mincey v. State, 314 S.C. 355, 368, 444 S.E.2d 510, 511 (1994), the court concluded it was error to allow closing argument about threats or dangers to witnesses unless there was evidence that connected the defendant to such threats. Â 
These cases seem to indicate, without so holding, that had the threats been connected to the defendant they would have been appropriately admitted into evidence. Â Obviously, such threats and other attempts to intimidate witnesses can and do result in criminal charges pursuant to section 16-9-340 of the South Carolina Code (Rev. 2003). Â See State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 613 S.E.2d 381 (Ct. App. 2005) (affirming defendantâ€™s conviction for intimidating victim/witness in connection with his trial for criminal sexual conduct).Â  
Lacking explicit precedent in this state, we turn to other jurisdictions to seek guidance.Â  In doing so, we find many other jurisdictions, particularly federal courts, including the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, have addressed the issue of the admissibility during the trial of threats against a witness made by the defendant.Â  The federal court cases generally conclude such threats indicate the defendantâ€™s â€œconsciousness of guiltâ€ and are therefore admissible pursuant to Rule 404(b) of the Federal Rules of Evidence.[4]Â  See U.S. v. Van Metre, 150 F.3d 339, 352 (4th Cir. 1998); U.S. v. Guerrero-Cortez, 110 F.3d 647, 652 (8th Cir. 1997) (acknowledging that â€œ[a]n effort to intimidate a witness tends to show consciousness of guiltâ€); U.S. v. Gatto, 995 F.2d 449, 454-55 (3d Cir. 1993) (holding that evidence of threats or intimidation of a witness is admissible under Rule 404(b) to show consciousness of guilt); U.S. v. Maddox, 944 F.2d 1223, 1230 (6th Cir. 1991) (â€œ[S]poliation evidence, including evidence that the defendant threatened a witness, is generally admissible because it is probative of consciousness of guilt.â€); U.S. v. Mickens, 926 F.2d 1323, 1329 (2d Cir. 1991) (holding that an effort to intimidate a witness is relevant to the issue of the defendantâ€™s state of mind and admissible under Rule 404(b)); U.S. v. Pina, 844 F.2d 1, 9 (1st Cir. 1988) (holding that defendantâ€™s threats against adverse witness is probative because it shows â€œthat the defendant is willing to go to extreme measures to exclude relevant evidence from trialâ€). Â 
Many state courts also permit the admission of evidence of threats against a witness.Â  See People v. Iannone, 769 N.Y.S.2d 676, 678 (2003) (â€œWhere, as here, there is some evidence connecting defendant to those threats, testimony concerning the threats is admissible on the issue of consciousness of guilt.â€); State v. Soke, 663 N.E.2d 986, 1001 (Ohio Ct. App. 1995) (â€œ[W]e note that evidence of threats or intimidation of witnesses reflects a consciousness of guilt and is admissible as admission by conduct.â€); State v. Hicks, 428 S.E.2d 167, 177 (N.C. 1993) (overruled on other grounds by State v. Buchanan, 543 S.E.2d 823 (N.C. 2001)) (â€œAn attempt by a defendant to intimidate a witness in an effort to prevent the witness from testifying or to induce the witness to testify falsely in his favor is relevant to show the defendantâ€™s awareness of his guilt.â€); Ransom v. State, 920 S.W.2d 288, 299 (Tex. Crim. App. 1994) (holding criminal acts designed to reduce the likelihood of conviction, including threats against witnesses, are admissible under Rule 404(b) as showing â€œconsciousness of guiltâ€); People v. Lucas, 603 N.E.2d 460, 486 (Ill. 1992) (â€œ[E]vidence of a plan to eliminate witnesses is admissible to show a consciousness of guilt where the scheme is connected to the defendant . . . .â€); Bain v. State, 521 S.E.2d 832, 835 (Ga. Ct. App. 1999) (admitting evidence of defendantâ€™s threats against prosecution witness as â€œindicating a consciousness of guiltâ€); Ragland v. Com., 434 S.E.2d 675, 679 (Va. Ct. App. 1993) (quoting McMillan v. Com., 50 S.E.2d 428, 430 (Va. 1948)) (â€œEvidence that a defendant â€˜procured, or attempted to procure, the absence of a witness, or to bribe or suppress testimony against him, is admissible, as it tends to show the unrighteousness of the defendantâ€™s cause and a consciousness of guilt.â€™â€); and People v. Pinholster, 824 P.2d 571, 611 (Cal. 1992) (admitting evidence of threatening phone call to prosecution witness as showing â€œconsciousness of guiltâ€).Â  
While the precedents from other jurisdictions are not controlling, we find them persuasive and in this case elect to adopt their analysis.Â  Just as conflicting statements and attempts to flee are indicative of â€œguilty knowledge and intent,â€[5] so too are the threats communicated here.Â  Consequently, the trial judge did not err in admitting the evidence regarding threats by Edwards against the victim/witness.Â  
We find the trial judge did not err in admitting prior acts of sexual conduct, denying a mistrial, and admitting evidence of threats against the victim.Â  The decision of the trial judge is accordingly
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

[1]  State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E.2d 803 (1923).Â  
[2]  State v. Mathis, 359 S.C. 450, 597 S.E.2d 872 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
[3]  The trial judge found this statement was not intentionally elicited by the prosecution.Â  
[4]  â€œEvidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith. Â It may, however, be admissible for other purposes, such as proof of motive, opportunity, intent, preparation, plan, knowledge, identity, or absence of mistake or accident . . . .â€Â  Fed. R. Evid. 404(b).Â  Rule 404(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence is similar to the federal rule, although as indicated by the reporterâ€™s comments, our state rule is slightly more restrictive regarding for what purposes evidence of other bad acts may be introduced.Â  It provides: Â â€œEvidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith.Â  It may, however, be admissible to show motive, identity, the existence of a common scheme or plan, the absence of mistake or accident, or intent.â€Â  Rule 404(b), SCRE.Â  
[5]  Town of Hartsville v. Munger, 93 S.C. 527, 529, 77 S.E. 219, 219 (1913); see also State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 655, 623 S.E.2d 122, 128 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œUnexplained flight is admissible as indicating consciousness of guilt, for it is not as likely that one who is blameless and conscious of that fact would flee.â€).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Vaughn Development, Inc., Respondent,
v.
Westvaco Development Corporation, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4214
Heard February 7, 2007 â€“ Filed March 12, 2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
G. Dana Sinkler, of Charleston; for Appellant.Â  
Frank M. Cisa, of Mt. Pleasant; for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Vaughn Development, Inc. filed this breach of contract action against Westvaco Development Corporation.Â  A jury awarded Vaughn Development $37,492.24, and the trial court awarded prejudgment interest.Â  Westvaco appeals the award of prejudgment interest.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
In 1999, Vaughn Development[1] purchased a 19 acre tract of land in Berkeley County from Westvaco for the purpose of developing the tract into single family lots.Â  The contract provided, in part:

That water, sanitary sewer, storm sewer and/or drainage outfalls are or shall be installed and operational within the road right-of-way adjacent to the boundary of the Property at no cost or expense to the Purchaser; that such utility installations are or shall be adequate and sufficient to provide such quantities, pressures, and capacities as will permit the utilization of the Property as herein contemplated, and that Purchaser shall be entitled to obtain, at Purchaserâ€™s expense, necessary water and sanitary sewer taps after payment of impact fees, if any, tap-on fees, and user charges as are normally and uniformly imposed by the utility companies or governmental agencies supplying such services[.] Â 

Steve Vaughn, President of Vaughn Development, testified that Joe Collins of Westvaco assured him that Westvaco would pay for the sewer installation.Â  Collins denied making any such assurance. Â 
Vaughn Development hired Superior Utilities, Inc. to install two sewer mains and manholes and four service crossings at a cost of $88,691. Â Vaughn Development requested reimbursement from Westvaco for this amount by letter dated September 9, 2002. Â The letter included Superior Utilitiesâ€™ cost detail. Â Westvaco responded by stating it would pay only $18,746.12 for the sewer work, which represented the cost of one sewer main based on Superior Utilitiesâ€™ cost detail. Â The jury awarded Vaughn Development $37,492.24, a sum equivalent to the cost of two sewer mains.Â  The court awarded Vaughn Development prejudgment interest.Â  Westvaco appeals.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Westvaco argues the trial court erred in awarding prejudgment interest because the measure of recovery could not have been determined at the time the claim arose.Â  We agree.Â  
Historically, the recovery of prejudgment interest was severely limited.Â  Michael S. Knoll, A Primer on Prejudgment Interest, 75 Tex. L. Rev. 293, 294-98 (1996).Â  â€œThe roots of prejudgment interest law are based on centuries-old moral and religious proscriptions against interest and loans.Â  Both the ancient Israelites and Greeks viewed the taking of any interest as usurious.â€Â  Martin Oyos, Comment, Prejudgment Interest in South Dakota, 33 S.D. L. Rev. 484, 485-86 (1988).Â  With the shift from agrarian economies in the common law European countries, and the emphasis in this country from the beginning on the mercantile influence, prejudgment interest has become more favored and the courts now allow prejudgment interest on liquidated amounts.Â  James L. Bernard, Note, Prejudgment Interest and the Copyright Act of 1976, 5 Fordham Intell. Prop. Media & Ent. L.J. 427, 433 (1995).Â  There has been, however, â€œgrowing dissatisfaction with the distinction between liquidated and unliquidated damages.Â  As a result, many jurisdictions abandoned it. . . .Â  With the breakdown and rejection of the distinction between liquidated and unliquidated damages, courts established more liberal rules for awarding prejudgment interest.Â  Some courts looked to whether the claim was â€˜ascertainable.â€™â€Â  Id. at 434-36.Â  This liberalization of prejudgment law has even led to recovery of prejudgment interest for personal injury damages, usually calculable from the time of a settlement offer or demand.Â  See generally Diane M. Allen, Annotation, Validity and Construction of State Statute or Rule Allowing or Changing Rate of Prejudgment Interest in Tort Actions, 40 A.L.R.4th 147 (1985) (cases and statutes cited therein).
Turning to South Carolina, we find an initial similar trend.Â  In the early part of the last century in South Carolina, the law regarding prejudgment interest was strict.Â  The failure of the party owing money to acknowledge a sum owed prevented a plaintiff from recovering prejudgment interest; the amount due had to be acknowledged and liquidated.Â 
Wakefield v. Spoon, 100 S.C. 100, 106, 84 S.E. 418, 420 (1915).Â  However, even under this specific rule, the law surrounding prejudgment interest was muddled.Â  Goddard v. Bulow, 10 S.C.L. (1 Nott & McC.) 45, 56 (1818) (â€œIt is not a little extraordinary that a question of every dayâ€™s occurrence, should have remained to this time unsettled . . . .â€).Â  Also similar to the trend in the United States, South Carolina liberalized the rules for awarding prejudgment interest.Â  The governing statute looks to whether the claim is ascertainable.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(A) (Supp. 2006) (â€œIn all cases of accounts stated and in all cases wherein any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained and, being due, shall draw interest according to law . . . .â€).Â  â€œIn South Carolina, interest may also be awarded in equity cases, conversion cases, and property cases.â€Â  11 S.C. Juris. Damages Â§ 8 (1992).
In recent years, our supreme court has explained that prejudgment interest is permitted by operation of law â€œif the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty.â€Â  Smith-Hunter Constr. Co. v. Hopson, 365 S.C. 125, 128, 616 S.E.2d 419, 421 (2005).Â  In Butler Contracting, Inc. v. Court Street, LLC, 369 S.C. 121, 631 S.E.2d 252 (2006) our supreme court explained:Â  

Stated another way, prejudgment interest is allowed on a claim of liquidated damages; i.e., the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty based on a mathematical calculation previously agreed to by the parties. Â Prejudgment interest is not allowed on an unliquidated claim in the absence of an agreement or statute.Â  The fact that the amount due is disputed by the opposing party does not render the claim unliquidated for the purposes of an award of prejudgment interest. Â 

Butler, 369 S.C. at 133, 631 S.E.2d at 258-59 (internal citations omitted).
Despite Smith-Hunter and Butler, the issue of prejudgment interest remains confusing and is often litigated.Â  Accordingly, as an intermediate appellate court, we are unwilling to go beyond these cases most recently decided by our supreme court.Â  Vaughn Development relies on these cases to support the award of prejudgment interest.Â  We find an award of prejudgment interest in this case would expand the interpretation of â€˜ascertainableâ€™ beyond that defined in Smith-Hunter and Butler Contracting.Â  
In Smith-Hunter, our supreme court affirmed an award of prejudgment interest in a breach of contract action brought by a builder against homeowners.Â  365 S.C. at 128-130, 616 S.E.2d at 421-22.Â  The court found â€œ[t]he measure of recovery was fixed by conditions existing at the time the claim arose.Â  The costs of the work completed by [the builder] at the time of [the homeownersâ€™] breach of contract were established via [the builderâ€™s] invoices.â€Â  Id. at 128, 616 S.E.2d at 421.Â  
In Butler, a subcontractor sought to recover in an action to enforce a mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  369 S.C. at 125-27, 631 S.E.2d at 254-55.Â  Our supreme court reversed the trial courtâ€™s denial of prejudgment interest finding although there was an obvious dispute as to the amount owed the subcontractor, â€œ[t]he proper test for determining whether prejudgment interest may be awarded is whether the measure of recovery, not necessarily the amount of damages, is fixed by conditions existing at the time the claim arose.â€Â  Id. at 133, 631 S.E.2d at 259.
Unlike Smith-Hunter and Butler Contracting, the measure of damages was not fixed in this case.Â  There was an intermediate question that had to be decided before the measure of damages could be ascertained.Â  Under the terms of the contract, the scope of the work required was not certain and the damages could only be measured after that determination was made.Â  The contract provided that the sewer installation â€œshall be adequate and sufficient to provide such quantities, pressures, and capacities as will permit the utilization of the Property as herein contemplated . . . .â€Â  We find the contract is not sufficiently specific to determine the extent of work required by its terms.Â  In addition to the extent of the work, the parties disputed the methods of installation and whether Westvaco would install the sewer or whether Vaughn Development would hire a subcontractor to do the necessary work.Â  These issues were not dictated in the contract.Â  The uncertainty regarding the extent and nature of the construction required under the terms of the contract is the primary factor that distinguishes this case from those relied upon by Vaughn Development.Â  
Because we find the measure of recovery was not fixed at the time the claim arose, we find the trial court erred in awarding prejudgment interest.Â  Accordingly, the award of prejudgment interest is
REVERSED. 
GOOLSBY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  Vaughn Development is a successor in interest under the contract between Westvaco and Vaughn Homes, Inc.

title: Mosseri v. Austinâ€™s at the Beach
description: The Court of Appeals reversed the circuit court's ruling affirming the magistrate's order retaining jurisdiction over the case brought by the plaintiff landlord against the defendant tenant.  The magistrate erred in retaining jurisdiction over the case pursuant to Section 22-3-10(10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) when the case did not involve the possession of land.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Mosseri, Mosseri, Castro, Respondent,
v.
Austinâ€™s at the Beach, Inc. and Paris, Inc., Defendants,
Of whom Austinâ€™s at the Beach is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â John L. Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4215
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 12, 2007Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Richard L. Whitt, Austin, Lewis & Rogers, P.A., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Mosseri, Mosseri, Castro, pro se, Respondents.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Austinâ€™s at the Beach (Austinâ€™s) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s ruling affirming the magistrateâ€™s order retaining jurisdiction over causes of action brought by the plaintiff landlord (Mosseri) against the defendant tenant (Austinâ€™s) and over the counterclaims brought by Austinâ€™s against Mosseri.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Mosseri owns commercial property in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, which has been used as a restaurant.Â  Mosseri leased the property to Paris, Inc., which later assigned the lease to Austinâ€™s.Â  Austinâ€™s operated a restaurant on the property for several years.Â  Rent for the property was payable in two installments of $14,000 due March 1 and September 1 of each year.Â  Austinâ€™s made a partial payment of $6,999 on September 1, 2000, leaving a balance of $7,001.Â  Austinâ€™s also failed to pay the water bill.Â Â Â  
Austinâ€™s claims it was justified in not paying the remaining rent on the property because it was in deplorable condition.Â  Austinâ€™s alleges the restaurant was electrically unsafe, was not heated or cooled, and had plumbing which was in a state of disrepair.Â  Austinâ€™s also avers that Mosseri placed a â€œfor rentâ€ sign in front of the restaurant, causing customers to be confused and ultimately hurting the business.Â  Consequently, on November 30, 2000, Austinâ€™s vacated the premises claiming it was constructively evicted.Â  
On February 13, 2001, Mosseri filed the underlying suit in magistrateâ€™s court for breach of the lease contract, demanding damages under the $7,500 jurisdictional limit.Â  Austinâ€™s counterclaimed alleging several causes of action including: (1) three causes of action for constructive eviction, seeking damages of $23,330, $5,835.50, and an amount to be determined; (2) conversion of electrical service; (3) two causes of action for unjust enrichment; (4) loss of business revenue totaling $8,500; and (5) failure to return the security deposit.Â  
Austinâ€™s attempted to remove the case to circuit court pursuant to Section 22-3-30 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) because two of Austinâ€™s counterclaims were for more than the $7,500 jurisdictional limit for magistrateâ€™s court.Â  The magistrateâ€™s court disagreed with Austinâ€™s and retained jurisdiction pursuant to Section 22-3-10 (10) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  Austinâ€™s filed a timely motion to reconsider, which was denied by the magistrateâ€™s court.Â  Austinâ€™s then filed a timely appeal to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court affirmed the magistrateâ€™s prior rulings.Â  This appeal follows.
DISCUSSION
Austinâ€™s claims the circuit court erred in affirming the magistrateâ€™s order retaining jurisdiction pursuant to Section 22-3-10 (10) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  We agree.
The magistrateâ€™s court has concurrent jurisdiction with the circuit court in contract actions for the recovery of money only, if the sum claimed does not exceed $7,500.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-10 (1) (Supp. 2005).Â  This jurisdictional limit does not apply to â€œmatters between landlord and tenant and the possession of land as provided in Chapters 33 through 41 of Title 27 . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-10 (10) (Supp. 2005).Â  The magistrateâ€™s court will retain jurisdiction in cases involving landlord and tenant and the possession of land even when any counterclaim exceeds $7,500.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-10 (12) (Supp. 2005).Â  In cases that do not fall under Section 22-3-10 (12) of the South Carolina Code â€œ[w]hen a counterclaim is filed which if successful would exceed the civil jurisdictional amount as provided in Section 22-3-10, then the initial claim and counterclaim must be transferred to the docket of the common pleas court for that judicial circuit.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-30 (Supp. 2005).
Chapters 33 through 41 of title 27 of the South Carolina Code deal with creation, construction and termination of leasehold estates, ejectment of tenants, rent, undertenants of life tenants, and the Residential Landlord Tenant Act (which is not applicable to non residential leaseholds).Â  The common theme of chapters 33 through 41 is possession of the property.Â Â Â Â  
Likewise, possession of the property must be in dispute for the case to fall under Section 22-3-10 (10) of the South Carolina Code.Â  Austinâ€™s argues that possession of the property is not an issue in any of the causes of action.Â  In fact, Austinâ€™s does not claim possession and Mosseri does not claim that Austinâ€™s is in wrongful possession of the property.Â  Austinâ€™s moved out of the property when it felt it had been constructively evicted.
While it is true this dispute is between a landlord and a tenant, Section 22-3-10 (10) specifically lists an additional requirement for the magistrateâ€™s court to retain jurisdiction: the dispute must involve a â€œlandlord and tenant and the possession of land.â€ (emphasis added). Â Because the statuteâ€™s language is clear and unambiguous and conveys a clear and definite meaning, there is no need for statutory interpretation by this Court.Â  See Grant v. City of Folly Beach, 346 S.C. 74, 79, 551 S.E.2d 229, 231 (2001).Â  
In this case, the two counterclaims that exceed the $7,500 jurisdictional limit clearly do not involve the possession of land as provided in chapters 33 through 41 of Title 27.Â  The constructive eviction cause of action merely seeks monetary damages caused by Mosseriâ€™s alleged failure to provide the tenant with property which was safe for the purposes for which it was leased.Â  Austinâ€™s was not in possession of the property and did not seek possession of the property when this case was filed.Â  The other cause of action, for loss of business revenue, is likewise not related to possession of the property.
Because possession of property was never an issue in the underlying case, nor in the counterclaims, and Austinâ€™s counterclaimed for amounts in excess of the magistrateâ€™s courtâ€™s jurisdictional limit as provided in Section 22-3-10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), this case should have been transferred to the court of common pleas pursuant to Section 22-3-30 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
REVERSED.[1]Â 
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
