description: The State appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding the State had not shown probable cause to believe Renauld L. Brown is a sexually violent predator.  We reverse and remand.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


Â THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
In the Matter of the Care and Treatment of Renauld L. Brown Respondent,
v.
The StateÂ Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4219
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 19, 2007

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, Assistant Attorney General Brandy A. Duncan, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
Renauld L. Brown, of Spartanburg, Pro Se Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Â Â The State appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding the State had not shown probable cause to believe Renauld L. Brown is a sexually violent predator.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
At approximately 6:00 a.m., on September 10, 2000, Renauld L. Brown was caught peeping in the windows of a thirty-six year old womanâ€™s home.Â  In November of that year, Brown was indicted on one count of eavesdropping/peeping tom for the incident.Â  Thereafter, Brown was seen looking into the same victimâ€™s windows on January 13, 2001 at approximately 3:00 a.m., and again on April 10, 2001 at 4:00 a.m. Â On October 10, 2001, Brown was convicted of one count of stalking and two counts of entering premises after notice in connection with the 2000 and two 2001 incidents.Â  He was sentenced to thirty days with credit for time served.Â  
On the evening of October 12, 2001, two days after being released from jail, Brown was seen peeping into the windows of the same womanâ€™s abode.Â  While his victim was on the telephone calling police, Brown attempted to break down her back door.Â  He was subsequently apprehended and charged with voyeurism, stalking, and attempted burglary.Â  On December 19, 2002, Brown was convicted on all three charges and sentenced to three years suspended to 433 days (time served) for voyeurism, one year for stalking, and five years suspended to 433 days (time served) for attempted burglary.
On January 13, 2003, twenty-five days after being released from jail on the December 2002 convictions, Brown was seen shortly before midnight peeping into the windows of a house belonging to the sister of the victim of his earlier offenses.Â  When police arrived, Brown attempted to flee but was captured after a brief foot chase.Â  After he was arrested and placed in the patrol car, Brown kicked one of the officers and began kicking the vehicleâ€™s doors.Â  He was charged with eavesdropping/peeping tom and resisting arrest. 
On January 7, 2005, Brown pled guilty to voyeurism and was sentenced to three years suspended to thirty months and three years probation, with credit for time served.Â  The sentencing judge made a specific finding that the offense should be considered a sexually violent act under the South Carolina Sexually Violent Predator Act (S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 44-48-10 to 44-48-170 (Supp. 2006)).Â  
Brown arrived at the South Carolina Department of Corrections on January 10, 2005, and was released on probation on January 11, 2005.Â  On June 4, 2005, less than six months after being released on probation, Brown was seen looking into the windows of yet another home.Â  The house belonged to a twenty-eight year old female, unrelated to his prior victims.Â  Brown pled guilty to one count of eavesdropping/peeping tom on June 29, 2005, and was sentenced to eighteen months incarceration, with the special condition that he receive mental health counseling.Â  
Pursuant to the Sexually Violent Predator Act, and particularly in light of the fact he had a previous qualifying offense, prior to Brownâ€™s release from the Department of Corrections, the multidisciplinary committee reviewed his case.Â  On October 24, 2005, the committee found probable cause to believe Brown to be a sexually violent predator.Â  On November 22, 2005, the prosecutorâ€™s review committee also found probable cause to believe Brown is a sexually violent predator and referred the case for further proceedings under the Act.Â  
On December 2, 2005, the State commenced an action seeking to commit Brown for long term control, care, and treatment.Â  The circuit judge found the Stateâ€™s petition set forth sufficient probable cause to believe Brown to be a sexually violent predator and ordered his detention pending a probable cause hearing.Â  
The matter was called for a probable cause hearing in the circuit court on February 15, 2006.Â  Brown was present with counsel.Â  The state argued Brownâ€™s history indicated he has a mental abnormality that causes him serious difficulty in controlling his deviant behavior.Â  The State further averred Brownâ€™s lack of sex offender treatment of any kind make him a significant risk to re-offend if not confined for long-term control, care and treatment.Â  In light of the evidence indicating Brownâ€™s inability to control his behavior and his significant risk to re-offend, the State asked the circuit court to find probable cause and order that Brown be evaluated by a qualified expert pursuant to the Code. 
Brown argued that even though his conduct was against the law, he had not committed an act of violence, and therefore, the State could not show probable cause that he would commit future acts of sexual violence. 

During the proceeding, the circuit court stated: 
  
[I]tâ€™s not like heâ€™s [Brown] just oblivious to the fact that [his offenses] ought to be considered some sort of deviant behavior.
    
. . .
    
He ought to have sense enough to know he needs counseling based upon his prior behavior.Â  And if he had that treatment or that counseling at his request, it might be that the state wouldnâ€™t even be here with this petition today, you see.
Thatâ€™s one concern they have, is that heâ€™s not received any treatment for his obvious misbehavior and itâ€™s likely that itâ€™s needed, and thatâ€™s likely to be true.Â  And therefore I say he ought to understand that just based on his prior behavior and his difficulties.Â  Thatâ€™s got nothing to do with probable cause.Â  
  

The circuit court dismissed the action, finding the State had not established probable cause to believe Brown is a sexually violent predator.Â  The entire substantive body of the judgeâ€™s order read:

This matter came before this Court for hearing on the petition of the petitioner, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Section 44-48-80, for the Court to determine whether probable cause exists to believe that the respondent is a sexually violent predator as defined in S.C. Code Ann. Section 44-48-30.Â  After a consideration of the showing made this Court finds that the Attorney General has failed to establish the existence of probable cause to believe that the respondent is a sexually violent predator and therefore the petition is dismissed with prejudice.Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œOn review, the appellate court will not disturb the hearing countâ€™s finding on probable cause unless found to be without evidence that reasonably supports the hearing courtâ€™s finding.â€Â  In re Care and Treatment of Tucker, 353 S.C. 466, 470, 578 S.E.2d 719, 721 (2003); see also In re Treatment and Care of Luckabaugh, 351 S.C. 122, 131, 568 S.E.2d 338, 342 (2002) (citing Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976)) (on appeal of a non-jury law case, the findings of fact will not be disturbed unless found to be without evidentiary support).Â  In an appeal regarding sufficiency of the evidence in a sexually violent predator case, we may only reverse the trial court if there is no evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  In re Care and Treatment of Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 59, 584 S.E.2d 893, 896 (2003) (citing In re Matthews, 345 S.C. 638, 646, 550 S.E.2d 311, 315 (2001)). Â In other words, this court is concerned with the existence of evidence, not its weight. Â Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
South Carolinaâ€™s Sexually Violent Predator Act (â€œSVP Actâ€ or â€œActâ€), S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 44-48-10 to 44-48-170 (Supp. 2006), provides for the involuntary civil commitment of sexually violent predators who are â€œmentally abnormal and extremely dangerous.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-20 (Supp. 2006).Â  The Act is not intended to be punitive in nature.Â  The quiddity of the act is to: (1) meet the special needs of sexually violent predators; (2) address the significant likelihood they will engage in repeated acts of sexual violence if not treated for their mental conditions; and (3) assess the risks requiring their involuntary civil commitment in a secure facility for long-term control, care, and treatment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-20 (Supp. 2006). Â Noting â€œthe nature of the mental conditions from which sexually violent predators suffer and the dangers they present,â€ our General Assembly found â€œit is necessary to house involuntary committed sexually violent predators in secure facilities separated from persons involuntarily committed under traditional civil commitment statutes.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-20 (Supp. 2006).
The SVP Act defines a â€œsexually violent predatorâ€ as a person who: â€œ(a) has been convicted of a sexually violent offense; and (b) suffers from a mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes the person likely to engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility for long-term control, care, and treatment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30 (1) (Supp. 2006).Â  
Commitment of someone under the SVP Act typically begins when a person convicted of a sexually violent offense is scheduled to be released from custody.Â  See S.C. Code Â§ 44-48-40(A) (Supp. 2006).Â  When a person has been imprisoned for a sexually violent offense, law requires that the agency with jurisdiction over that person give notice to both the Attorney General and a multidisciplinary team specially designed to evaluate the particular offender.Â  Id.Â  Typically, such notice must be provided in writing at least one hundred eighty days prior to the personâ€™s release.Â  See Â§ 44-48-40(A)(1) (Supp. 2006). 
The multidisciplinary team must consist of: â€œ(1) a representative from the Department of Corrections; (2) a representative from the Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services; (3) a representative from the Department of Mental Health who is a trained, qualified mental health clinician with expertise in treating sexually violent offenders; (4) a retired judge appointed by the Chief Justice who is eligible for continued judicial service pursuant to Section 2-19-100; and (5) an attorney with substantial experience in the practice of criminal defense law to be appointed by the Chief Justice to serve a term of one year.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-50 (Supp. 2006).Â  This team reviews the personâ€™s records to determine if he or she satisfies the definition of a sexually violent predator.Â  Id.Â  If the multidisciplinary team determines that the person meets the definition, the body forwards its assessment and all relevant records to a prosecutorâ€™s review committee.Â  Id.
The prosecutorâ€™s review committee then â€œdetermine[s] whether or not probable cause exists to believe the person is a sexually violent predator.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-60 (Supp. 2006).Â  In additional to the records and reports provided by the multidisciplinary team, the committee must consider any information provided by the circuit solicitor who originally prosecuted the person.Â  Id.Â  
If the prosecutorâ€™s review committee finds probable cause exists to believe the person is sexually violent predator, the Attorney General must file a petition asking the court to make a probable cause determination.Â  

When the prosecutor's review committee has determined that probable cause exists to support the allegation that the person is a sexually violent predator, the Attorney General must file a petition with the court in the jurisdiction where the person committed the offense and must notify the victim that the committee found that probable cause exists. The Attorney General must also notify the victim of the time, date, and location of the probable cause hearing before the court. The petition, which must be filed within thirty days of the probable cause determination by the prosecutor's review committee, must request that the court make a probable cause determination as to whether the person is a sexually violent predator. The petition must allege that the person is a sexually violent predator and must state sufficient facts that would support a probable cause allegation.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-70 (Supp. 2006).
Â â€œUpon filing of a petition, the court must determine whether probable cause exists to believe that the person named in the petition is a sexually violent predator.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(A) (Supp. 2006).Â  The probable cause hearing is required within seventy-two hours after the person is taken into custody.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(B) (Supp. 2006).Â  At the hearing, the law instructs the court to:Â  â€œ(1) verify the detaineeâ€™s identity; (2) receive evidence and hear arguments from the person and the Attorney General; and (3) determine whether probable cause exists to believe that the person is a sexually violent predator.â€Â  Id.Â  The suspected predator is guaranteed: â€œ(1) to be represented by counsel; (2) to present evidence on the personâ€™s behalf; (3) to cross-examine witnesses who testify against the person; and (4) to view and copy all petitions and reports in the court file.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(B) (Supp. 2006).Â  
â€œIf the court determines that probable cause exists to believe that the person is a sexually violent predator, the person must be taken into custody if he is not already confined in a secure facility,â€ in order to await his or her commitment trial to be held.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(A) (Supp. 2006).Â  This trial will be heard by a judge unless the detainee or Attorney General requests a jury trial.Â  The State has the burden to prove the person is a sexually violent predator beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  In the Matter of the Care and Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 60, 584 S.E.2d 893, 896 (2003); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-100 (Supp. 2006).
The undisputed evidence presented to the circuit court at Brownâ€™s probable cause hearing established a clear pattern of sexually deviant behavior.Â  Luculently, the existence of probable cause to believe he was a sexually violent person was validated.
â€œProbable cause is a flexible, common-sense standard.â€ State v. Bowie, 360 S.C. 210, 220, 600 S.E.2d 112, 117 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Texas v. Brown, 460 U.S. 730, 103 S. Ct. 1535, 75 L. Ed. 2d 502 (1983)).Â  The very term itself, â€œprobable cause,â€ does not import absolute certainty. State v. Bennett, 256 S.C. 234, 182 S.E.2d 291 (1971); State v. Arnold, 319 S.C. 256, 460 S.E.2d 403 (Ct. App. 1995). Â 
In looking at probable cause determining whether a search warrant should be issued, this court has stated that magistrates are to concern themselves with probabilities and not certainties. Â State v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221, 251, 609 S.E.2d 572, 587 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Bowie, 360 S.C. at 220, 600 S.E.2d at 117.)Â  In regard to the lawfulness of an arrest, probable cause â€œmerely requires that the facts available to the officer would â€˜warrant a man of reasonable caution in the beliefâ€™ â€ that an offense has been committed and that the accused committed it. Â Brown, 460 U.S. at 742, 103 S. Ct. 1535 (quoting Carroll v. United States, 267 U.S. 132, 162, 45 S. Ct. 280, 69 L. Ed. 543 (1925)). Â Probable cause may be found somewhere between suspicion and sufficient evidence to convict.Â  State v. Blassingame, 338 S.C. 240, 250, 525 S.E.2d 535, 540-41 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Thompson v. Smith, 289 S.C. 334, 336-37, 345 S.E.2d 500, 502 (Ct. App. 1986), overruled in part on other grounds by Jones v. City of Columbia, 301 S.C. 62, 389 S.E.2d 662 (1990)).
In the context of probable cause to believe someone to be a sexually violent predator, probable cause requires that the evidence presented would lead a reasonable person to believe and conscientiously entertain suspicion that the person meets the definition of a sexually violent predator.Â  See People v. Hardacre, 109 Cal. Rptr. 2d 667, 673 (Cal. App. 2 Dist. 2001); see also Matter of Hay, 953 P.2d 666, 676 (Kan. 1998) (a probable cause determination in a sexual predator case requires evidence sufficient for a person of ordinary prudence and action to conscientiously entertain a reasonable belief that the person in question is a sexually violent predator).Â  Probable cause â€œdoes not demand any showing that such a belief be correct or more likely true than false.â€ Â Brown, 460 U.S. at 742, 103 S. Ct. 1535.Â  
In a seven-month span in 2000 and 2001, Brown was discovered peeping into the same victimâ€™s windows on three separate occasions, the latter two incidents occurring after he had already been indicted for the first.Â  Only two days after completing his first sentence, Brown was apprehended for recommitting his previous offense, this time attempting to break down the womanâ€™s door.Â  He was imprisoned and shortly after being released from confinement was caught peeping in windows at the home of the previous victimâ€™s sister.Â  During this arrest, Brown behaved violently.Â  He resisted capture and kicked a police officer in the process.Â  After being incarcerated for approximately two years for this offense, Brown was yet again found looking into someoneâ€™s home.
This chronology demonstrates a disturbing pattern, no sign of rehabilitation or remorse, and shows increasingly violent aspects of deviant behavior.Â  A personâ€™s dangerous propensities to commit future acts of sexual violence are the focus of the SVP Act.Â  See In re Care and Treatment of Corely, 353 S.C. 202, 207, 577 S.E.2d 451, 454 (2003).Â  There is brobdingnagian evidence in the record indicating Brown suffers from voyeurism, a condition that involves recurrent, intense sexually arousing fantasies, sexual urges or behaviors involving the act of watching an unsuspecting person who is naked or in the process of disrobing, or engaging in sexual activity.Â  Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, (â€œDSM-IVâ€), 532 (4th ed. 1994).Â  There is plenitudinous evidence to support a reasonable belief and suspicion that Brown meets the definition of a sexually violent predator.Â  Brown: (1) has been convicted of a sexually violent offense; and (2) most probably suffers from a mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes the person likely to engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility for long-term control, care, and treatment.
That Brown was not violent, per se, toward any of his victims is of no consequence.Â  The Codeâ€™s definition of â€œsexually violent offenseâ€ lists fifteen specific criminal sexual offenses, as well as â€œany offense for which the judge makes a specific finding on the record that based on the circumstances of the case, the personâ€™s offense should be considered a sexually violent offense.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(2) (Supp 2006).Â  Many of the listed offenses do not require an overt act of violence.Â  Section 44-48-30(2) includes the crimes of incest, buggery, committing or attempting a lewd act upon a child under the age of sixteen, and accessory before the fact to commit any of the other offenses enumerated in the section.Â  Such offenses can unequivocally be accomplished without aggression, the use of great force, or having serious physical harm or injury result. Â It is apodictic that in order to qualify as a sexually violent offense, oneâ€™s actions do not have be violent in the sense of being physically injurious or destructive.
The determination was made by the sentencing judge that, under these particular facts and circumstances, Brownâ€™s eavesdropping/peeping tom amounted to a sexually violent offense.Â  The facts and circumstances necessary to qualify his offense as a sexually violent one are indubitably present.Â  Brownâ€™s intrusion violated the sanctity of these victimâ€™s homes.Â  His actions were unquestionably gravely injurious to the psyche and emotional well-being of these women.Â  Furthermore, the repetitious nature of his behavior conforms to the definition of a predator.Â  â€œPredatoryâ€ is defined as â€œshowing a disposition to injure or exploit others for oneâ€™s own gain.â€Â  Websterâ€™s New Collegiate Dictionary 898 (1979).
Additionally, Brown committed acts of violence.Â  Â In connection with two of his voyeurism incidents, he attempted to break down one victimâ€™s door, resisted arrest, and kicked a law enforcement official.Â  Such behavior indicates that Brownâ€™s urges transcend the act of passively watching women through their windows at night.
A cursory reading of the transcript reveals the circuit court believed there was sufficient evidence to suggest Brown suffers from sexually deviant urges and needs therapy and psychiatric care.Â  The court stated that Brown should â€œknow he needs counseling based upon his prior behavior,â€ and that the Stateâ€™s contention that Brown needed sex offender treatment was â€œlikely to be true.â€Â  Yet incredibly, the circuit court stated Brownâ€™s need for treatment â€œbased upon his prior behavior and his difficultiesâ€ had â€œnothing to do with probable cause.â€Â  In contrariety, the need for treatment to prevent repeat offenses is the central focus of the SVP Act, and thus is directly relevant to such probable cause determinations.Â  In the face of those statements on the record, however, the circuit court inexplicably found no probable cause and dismissed the case.
The circuit courtâ€™s finding of no probable cause is not supported by the evidence.Â  It is in contraposition to the record as well as the courtâ€™s stated recognition that Brown has deviant urges and needs treatment.Â  If the circuit courtâ€™s order is given viability, Brown will not be evaluated to determine the extent of his obvious sexually deviant urges and what treatment he needs to control them.Â  Rather, he will remain free to terrorize other unsuspecting females, and will not receive the treatment he requires.
CONCLUSION 
We hold that the trial record irrefutably establishes probable cause within the mandate of the South Carolina Sexually Violent Predator Act.Â  We come to the adamantine and inescapable conclusion that the evidentiary record dictates REVERSAL. 
This case is remanded to the circuit court for further proceedings in accordance with the South Carolina Sexually Violent Predator Act, including a psychiatric evaluation and a trial on the merits. 
ACCORDINGLY, THE ORDER OF THE CIRCUIT JUDGE IS 
REVERSED AND THE CASE IS REMANDED.
KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Eugene Jamison and Delores Isaac, individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of Virnell Isaac,
Appellants,
v.
Ford Motor Company, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Berkeley County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4220
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 19, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephanie P. McDonald and Samuel K. Allen, both of Charleston; and James E. Carter, of Savannah, for Appellants.
J. Kenneth Carter, Jr., of Columbia; David R. Kelley and Wayne D. Struble, both of Minneapolis; and Jeffery T. Gorcyca, of Detroit, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Eugene Jamison and Delores Isaac, individually and as Personal Representatives of the Estate of Virnell Isaac (collectively Jamison), appeal the circuit courtâ€™s: (1) exclusion of expert testimony and video evidence; and (2) denial of Jamisonâ€™s motions for sanctions and relief from judgment.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In July 1998, Virnell Isaac suffered major injuries to her liver when the 1993 Escort she was driving was involved in a frontal, angular collision with another car.Â  Isaac died several days later as a result of the injuries sustained in the accident.Â Â Â  
Jamison filed a wrongful death action against Ford Motor Company (Ford) alleging, in relevant part, that Isaac suffered fatal injuries because Ford negligently designed and implemented the driverâ€™s occupant protection system.[2]Â  Ford equipped the 1993 Escort with a driverâ€™s side passive restraint system employing various components that worked collectively to protect the driver in frontal, angular collisions.Â  The passive restraint system components included: (1) an automatic, motorized shoulder belt that positioned itself over the occupant without any action by the occupant; (2) a seat pan; (3) a knee bolster; and (4) an energy absorbing car body.Â  The restraint system required no affirmative action by the driver, making it completely passive and in compliance with Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 208.Â  The 1993 Escort was additionally equipped with a manual lap belt that required affirmative action from the passenger or driver to engage it.Â  Jamison specifically complained that Ford negligently designed and implemented the various components of the restraint system, including the manual lap belt, the knee bolster, and the seat pan.Â  
During discovery Jamison requested crash test reports and full videos of 1991 through 1993 Ford Escort crash tests.Â  Ford responded by producing a summary of certification tests, but referred Jamison to Mazda, the company that conducted the requested crash tests, for the detailed reports and actual videos.Â  Ford provided 1994 through 1996 Ford Escort crash test reports and videos.Â  However, the 1994 through 1996 models, unlike the 1991 through 1993 models, were equipped with driver and passenger side airbag restraint systems.Â  
In October 2003, Jamison filed a â€œMotion to Compel Production of Documents.â€Â  Jamison asked the court to order Fordâ€™s production of the 1991 through 1993 test reports and videos.Â  Additionally, Jamison urged that Ford be required to provide complete video tests, noting that the videos Ford had produced were â€œmissing significant portions of the crash tests.â€ Â Jamison sought sanctions against Ford for discovery abuses, claiming Ford had intentionally delayed discovery by submitting duplicative and non-responsive documents.Â  The circuit court agreed Ford must supply the materials requested; however, the court refrained from imposing sanctions due to Fordâ€™s representation that the documents would be delivered.Â  Ford subsequently surrendered a â€œsmall group of Mazda crash testsâ€ and certified that all materials from Mazda regarding the crash tests had been yielded.Â  
Ford filed motions in limine to exclude certain theories of liability Jamison asserted.Â  Specifically, Ford contended (1) Jamison was preempted by Federal law from arguing Fordâ€™s choice of the passive restraint system installed in the Escort was defective, i.e. that another type of restraint system would have prevented Isaacâ€™s injuries; (2) Jamison was preempted from challenging the geometry of the manual lap belt design; and (3) Jamisonâ€™s claim that the manual lap belt design was defective should be excluded because no reasonable evidence existed to indicate Isaac wore the manual lap belt and that its defective design proximately caused her injuries. 
The circuit court ruled: (1) federal regulations preempted Jamison from challenging Fordâ€™s choice of restraint system; (2) testimony suggesting a manual lap belt should have been a component of the 1993 Escortâ€™s passive restraint system was excluded because such evidence challenged Fordâ€™s choice of restraint system; andÂ  (3) Jamison was allowed to present evidence that the design of the passive restraint system was defective; however, anyÂ  testimony that the passive restraint system was defective without a manual lap belt was preempted.
In January 2004, Jamison filed a motion for sanctions against Ford for alleged ongoing discovery abuse.Â  Jamison argued a default judgment should be entered against Ford for willful and intentional failure to produce certain crash test data that Jamison received on January 19, 2004 from another source.[3] Â The circuit court declined to enter a default judgment without having an opportunity to review the evidence and determine its prejudicial effect.Â  
Immediately prior to trial, the circuit court again considered various pending motions, including Jamisonâ€™s motion for default judgment.Â  At that time, Jamison informed the circuit court that additional videotapes of crash tests showing more views of occupant kinematics in the 1993 Escort had been discovered.Â  Jamison urged the court to sanction Ford by prohibiting references to the 1993 Escortâ€™s compliance with federal regulations.Â  The circuit court held Jamison failed to demonstrate Fordâ€™s conduct warranted such sanctions, and the motion was denied. 
During the pre-trial hearing, the circuit court revisited the issue of Jamisonâ€™s defective lap belt claim.Â  The circuit court held â€œ[t]he lap belt . . . argument is preempted,â€ and Jamison cannot â€œcriticize the lap belt.â€Â  However, the court held that â€œthe effectiveness of [the passive restraint] system, what it was designed and intended to do is subject to challenge . . . .â€Â  The court confirmed that, in order to prove negligence based on any defective restraint system, Jamison must prove proximate cause.Â  
The case was tried before a jury in February 2004.Â  Jamison attempted to introduce a crash test video conducted on a 1995 vehicle that was identical to Isaacâ€™s 1993 Escort, except the 1995 vehicle was equipped with air bags.Â  Jamison submitted that the tests demonstrated occupant kinematics.Â  Ford objected to the tests based on the prejudicial effect of the air bag.Â  The circuit court excluded the video under Rule 403, SCRE, concluding the probative value of the video was substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, and potential to mislead the jury.Â  The jury returned a verdict in Fordâ€™s favor.Â  
Subsequently, Jamison received a brochure advertising a 1993 European Escort.Â  Jamison filed a Rule 60(b) motion for relief from judgment arguing the newly discovered evidence demonstrated the feasibility of an alternative design and further substantiated claims of Fordâ€™s discovery abuse.Â  The circuit court found the brochure was cumulative and Jamison was not prejudiced by non-disclosure of the brochure.Â  Jamisonâ€™s motion for relief from judgment was denied
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Expert Testimony 
Jamison argues the circuit court erred in excluding expert testimony relating to the geometry and design of the manual lap belt Ford had installed in the 1993 Escort.Â  Specifically, Jamison maintains the circuit court erred as a matter of law in relying on its interpretation of Geier v. Am. Honda Motor Co., Inc., 529 U.S. 861 (2000), that any challenge to the passive restraint system based upon the alleged defective manual lap belt was preempted.Â  We disagree.Â  
Ford contends this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  The failure to make a proffer of excluded evidence will preclude review on appeal.Â  State v. Simmons, 360 S.C. 33, 46, 599 S.E.2d 448, 454 (2004); TNS Mills, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 503 S.E.2d 471 (1998). Â Generally, a party must request the opportunity to present an expert witness in order for the issue to be preserved for appellate review.Â  State v. Beam, 336 S.C. 45, 51-52, 518 S.E.2d 297, 301 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  It is well settled that a reviewing court may not consider error claimed in the exclusion of testimony unless the record on appeal shows fairly what the rejected testimony would have been.Â  State v. Roper, 274 S.C. 14, 20, 260 S.E.2d 705, 708 (1979).Â  However, this rule regarding proffers has been relaxed where the appellate court is able determine from the record what the testimony was intended to show and that prejudice clearly exists.Â  State v. Jenkins, 322 S.C. 360, 367, 474 S.E.2d 812, 816 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
In this case, the record sufficiently identifies the testimony Jamison sought to introduce regarding the use of and alleged defects of the manual lap belt.Â  Furthermore, as Jamison averred, the exclusion of expert testimony regarding the manual lap belt prevented Jamison from being able to â€œproperly criticize the seatbelt design or to explain the full geometry of the defects in the belt system.â€Â  Initially, Jamisonâ€™s â€œprimary criticism [was] aimed at lower torso restraint in this configuration, or lack thereof.â€Â  The improper exclusion of the manual lap belt evidence would indubitably prejudice Jamison.Â  Therefore, this issue is preserved for appellate review.Â  
On the merits, the admissibility of an expertâ€™s testimony is a matter within the circuit courtâ€™s sound discretion. Â Fields v. Regional Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 25, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005); State v. Douglas, 367 S.C. 498, 626 S.E.2d 59 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. pending; State v. Harris, 318 S.C. 178, 456 S.E.2d 433 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision to admit expert testimony will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Â State v. Myers, 359 S.C. 40, 51, 596 S.E.2d 488, 494 (2004); Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 570 S.E.2d 176 (2002); State v. Grubbs, 353 S.C. 374, 577 S.E.2d 493 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Henry, 329 S.C. 266, 495 S.E.2d 463 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œAn
abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Douglas, 367 S.C. at 507, 626 S.E.2d at 64.Â  Â 
To warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the complaining party must prove both the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice. Â Vaught v. A.O. Hardee & Sons, Inc., 366 S.C. 475, 480, 623 S.E.2d 373, 374 (2005); Fields, 363 S.C. at 26, 609 S.E.2d at 509; Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 595 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 2004). Â To show prejudice, there must be a reasonable probability that the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the challenged evidence or the lack thereof.Â  Fields, 363 S.C. at 26, 609 S.E.2d at 509.
A.  Federal Preemption Under National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act of 1966,
Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 208, the â€œSaving Clause,â€ and Geier v. American Honda Motor Company 
A priori, the initial issue in the case sub judice is whether by express federal preemption this state common law tort action is barred.Â  Briefly, we review the federal preemption principles explicated in King v. Ford Motor Co., 209 F.3d 886, 891 (2000).

The Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution provides that federal law â€œshall be the supreme Law of the Land . . . any Thing in the Constitution or Laws of and State to the Contrary notwithstanding.â€ Â U.S. Const. art. VI. Thus, as has been clear since the Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in Mâ€™Culloch v. Maryland, 17 U.S. (4 Wheat.), 316, 4 L. Ed. 579 (1819), any state law that conflicts with federal law is â€œwithout effect.â€ Â Cipollone v. Liggett Group, Inc., 505 U.S. 504, 516, 112 S. Ct. 2608, 120 L.Ed.2d 407 (1992) (citing Maryland v. Louisiana, 451 U.S. 725, 746, 101 S. Ct. 2114, 68 L.Ed.2d 576 (1981)).
In applying the Supremacy Clause, courts â€œstart with the assumption that the historic police powers of the States [are] not to be superseded by [a] Federal Act unless that was the clear and manifest purpose of Congress.â€ Â Medtronic v. Lohr, 518 U.S. 470, 485, 116 S. Ct. 2240, 135 L.Ed.2d 700 (1996) (citing Rice v. Santa Fe Elevator Corp., 331 U.S. 218, 230, 67 S. Ct. 1146, 91 L. Ed. 1447 (1947)). Â Therefore, â€œ â€˜[t]he purpose of Congress is the ultimate touchstoneâ€™ in every pre-emption case.â€Â  Id. (citing Cipollone, 505 U.S. at 516, 112 S. Ct. 2608). Â The Supreme Court has stated that Congress may make its intent to preempt clear either expressly or implicitly. Â See Freightliner Corp. v. Myrick, 514 U.S. 280, 287, 115 S. Ct. 1483, 131 L. Ed.2d 385 (1995). Â Implied preemption, in turn, takes two forms. Â â€œWe have found implied conflict pre-emption where it is impossible for a private party to comply with both state and federal requirements, or where state law stands as an obstacle to the accomplishment and execution of the full purposes and objectives of Congress.â€ Â Id. (internal citations and quotations omitted). Â In summary, then, there are three types of preemption-express preemption, implied conflict preemption, and implied field preemption.[4]

The cognoscenti of federal preemption jurisprudence bestow panoramic application so as to limit state common law tort actions.Â  We decline to accept this broad-brush federal judicial barricade.Â  
1.  National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act of 1966 (Safety Act) (80 Stat. 718, 15 U.S.C. Â§ 1381 et seq. (1988 ed.)
The express preemption provision contained in section 1392(d) of the Safety Act reads:

Whenever a Federal motor vehicle safety standard established under this subchapter is in effect, no State or political subdivision of a State shall have any authority either to establish, or to continue in effect, with respect to any motor vehicle or item or motor vehicle equipment any safety standard applicable to the same aspect of performance of such vehicle or item of equipment which is not identical to the Federal standard.Â  

15 U.S.C. Â§ 1392(d) (1988 ed.).
2.  Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 208 
 Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard (FMVSS) 208, promulgated under the authority of the Safety Act, specifies performance requirements for the protection of vehicle occupants in crashes.Â  49 C.F.R. Â§ 571.208 (2006).Â  FMVSS 208 establishes the various restraint systems manufacturers must install to comply with federal regulations; the requirements differ depending on the year the car was manufactured.Â  Id.Â  The version of FMVSS 208 in effect when the 1993 Escort was produced required automobile makers to certify passenger cars with a completely passive restraint system:

S4.1.2.1 First optionâ€”frontal/angular automatic protection system.Â  The vehicle shall:
  
(a) At each front outboard designated seating position meet the frontal crash protection requirements of S5.1 buy means that requires no action by vehicle occupants.
  

49 C.F.R. Â§ 571.208 (1992 ed.).
Manufacturers had the option of certifying passenger cars with either an automatic seat belt or an airbag.Â  The Department of Transportation permitted manufacturers to meet the automatic seat belt option requirement using belts that provided only upper torso restraint:[5]

S4.5.3Â  Automatic belts:Â  Except as provided in S4.5.3.1, a seat belt assembly that requires no action by vehicle occupants (hereinafter referred to as an â€œautomatic beltâ€) may be used to meet the crash protection requirements of any option under S4 and in place of any seat belt assembly otherwise required by that option.Â  
S4.5.3.2Â  An automatic belt, furnished pursuant to S4.5.3, that provides both pelvic and upper torso restraint may have either a detachable or nondetachable upper torso portion, notwithstanding provisions of the option under which it is furnished.

Id.

FMVSS 208 was viewed:
not as a minimum standard, but as a way to provide a manufacturer with a range of choices among different passive restraint systems that would be gradually introduced, thereby lowering costs, overcoming technical safety problems, encouraging technological development, and winning widespread consumer acceptableâ€”all of which would promote FMVSS 208â€™s safety objectives.

Geier v. Am. Honda Motor Co., Inc., 529 U.S. 861, 862 (2000).Â  
 3.  The Saving Clause
Regulation FMVSS 208, together with the Safety Actâ€™s express preemption provision, precludes States from setting safety standards that are not identical to the federal standard set forth in FMVSS 208.Â  However, Section 1397(k) of the Safety Act establishes that â€œ[c]ompliance with any Federal motor vehicle safety standard issued under this subchapter does not exempt any person from any liability under common law.â€Â  See Â Geier, 529 U.S. at 895.Â  The presence of this saving clause â€œrequires that the pre-emption provision be read narrowly to pre-empt only state statutes and regulations.â€ Id. at 861.Â  The majority in Geier observed that: 

[w]ithout a saving clause, a broad reading of the express pre-emption provision arguably might pre-empt those actions . . . as applying to standards imposed in common-law tort actions, as well as standards contained in state legislation or regulations.Â  And if so, it would pre-empt all nonidentical state standards established in tort actions covering the same aspect of performance as an applicable federal standard, even if the federal standard merely established a minimum standard.Â  On that broad reading of the pre-emption clause little, if any, potential â€œliability at common lawâ€ would remain. . . .Â  We have found no convincing indication that Congress wanted to pre-empt, not only state statutes and regulations, but also common-law tort actions, in such circumstances. 

Geier, 529 U.S.C. at 868.
Importantly, scholars on basic conflict preemption principles inculcate in regard to the fundamental elixir of the rule when juxtaposing federal/state constitutional analysis.Â  If a state statute, administrative rule, or common law cause of action conflicts with a federal statute, it is incontestable that the state law has no efficacy.Â  It is pellucid that the Supremacy Clause does not bless unelected federal judges with carte blanche to utilize federal law as a conduit to impose their own views of tort law on the States.Â  Assumptively, we recognize that common law tort actions are historically within the scope of the Statesâ€™ police powers and are safe from preemption by a federal statute unless Congress reveals a clear and manifest purpose to preempt.Â  
4.  Geier v. American Honda Motor Company 
The Geier court reasoned that the saving clause â€œat leastâ€ removed common law tort actions from the scope of the express preemption clause, but neither the saving clause nor the express preemption provision barred the ordinary working of conflict preemption principles.Â  Geier v. Am. Honda Motor Co., Inc., 529 U.S. 861, 869 (2000).Â  The majority cautioned that â€œ[n]othing in the language of the saving clause suggests an intent to save state-law tort actions that conflict with federal regulations.â€Â  Id.Â 
In Geier, a young man suffered injuries while driving a 1987 Honda Accord equipped with manual shoulder and lap belts but no driverâ€™s side airbag.Â  529 U.S. at 865.Â  Under FMVSS 208, Honda had the choice of whether or not to equip the 1987 Accord with an airbag.Â  Id.Â  Applying conflict preemption principles, the supreme court held plaintiffsâ€™ contention that the Accord should have been equipped with an airbag was preempted because the argument â€œstood as an obstacle to the accomplishment and execution of the important . . . federal objectives [to promote safety by allowing manufacturers to install alternative protection systems].â€ Â 529 U.S. at 881 (internal citations and quotations omitted).Â  Thus, under Geier, a manufacturerâ€™s choice of restraint system cannot be challenged if it complies with the requirements under FMVSS 208.Â  Â 
Plaintiffs are not preempted from asserting a defect in the design or implementation of a chosen passive restraint system.Â  See King v. Ford Motor Co., 209 F.3d 886, 892 (2000). Â The King court emphasized that â€œcompliance with performance criteria does not immunize manufacturers from common law liability arising from any defects in the production or design of their passive restraint systems.â€Â  Id. (internal citations omitted) Â (â€œ[T]he very federal safety statute upon which GM relies makes it abundantly clear that compliance with the regulations promulgated thereunder does not immunize a manufacturer from common law liability.â€ (citing 15 U.S.C. Â§ 1397(c) (1976))).Â  
In the instant case, Isaac sustained her injuries in a frontal, angular collision.Â  Pursuant to FMVSS 208, the 1993 Escort had to â€œmeet the frontal crash protection requirements [established by FMVSS 208] by means that require no action by vehicle occupants.â€Â  49 C.F.R. Â§ 571.208 (1992 ed.) (emphasis added).Â  Ford was required to provide a passive restraint system that secures passengers without the use of any manual elements.Â  Ford chose to equip the 1993 Escort with a driverâ€™s side passive restraint system employing various components that worked collectively to protect the driver and complied with FMVSS 208. Â The components included: (1) an automatic, motorized shoulder belt; (2) a seat pan; (3) a knee bolster; and (4) an energy absorbing car body. 
Based on the Safety Act, FMVSS 208, the saving clause, and Geier, Jamison was preempted from claiming the manual lap belt was defective in geometry or design.Â  Notably a lap belt was not part of the passive restraint system chosen by Ford or required by the FMVSS; Ford included the manual lap belt in compliance with other federal regulations to protect occupants against lateral crashes and rollovers.Â  As Jamisonâ€™s trial counsel acknowledged in a pre-trial hearing: â€œ[I]tâ€™s not going to make any difference. . . whether you have a lap belt on or not because Ford depends on [other components] to restrain the lower torsoâ€ in collisions like the one in this case.Â  Thus, allowing Jamison to challenge the geometry or design of the manual lap belt would be tantamount to allowing Jamison to argue Ford should have included a lap belt that effectively restrains the torso.Â  Such an argument clearly challenges Fordâ€™s choice of occupant restraint systems and is preempted by Geier.Â  The circuit court did not abuse its discretion in excluding Jamisonâ€™s expert testimony regarding the manual lap belt.Â  Moreover, the circuit court appropriately advised the jury about the irrelevance of the lap belt in the following instruction:

[I]n this particular dispute . . . the use, design or performance of a lap belt is not in question.Â  It is not an issue and itâ€™s not to be considered by you in this.Â  You will see it and observe it [in various exhibits] but it has no significance in this dispute for your purposes or your consideration.

On appeal, Jamison suggests the jury was left to wonder about the role the lap belt played, or would have played, in protecting Isaac.Â  Nevertheless, we determine the circuit courtâ€™s instruction sufficiently informed the jury that the lap belt was not to be considered.Â Â  
 B. Proximate Cause
As an additional basis for exclusion of evidence regarding Jamisonâ€™s defective lap belt claim, Ford contends Jamison failed to establish any reliable proof that a lap belt design defect proximately caused Isaacâ€™s fatal injuries. Â Proximate cause requires proof of causation in fact and legal cause. Â Bray v. Marathon Corp., 356 S.C. 111, 116-17, 588 S.E.2d 93, 95 (2003); Trivelas v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 558 S.E.2d 271 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Causation in fact is proved by establishing the injury would not have occurred â€œbut forâ€ the defendantâ€™s negligence.Â  Small v. Pioneer Mach., Inc., 329 S.C. 448, 463, 494 S.E.2d 835, 842 (Ct. App. 1997). Â Legal cause is proved by establishing foreseeability.Â  Bray, 356 S.C. at 117, 588 S.E.2d at 95; Small, 329 S.C. at 463, 494 S.E.2d at 842.Â  The touchstone of proximate cause in South Carolina is foreseeability.Â  Koester v. Carolina Rental Ctr., Inc., 313 S.C. 490, 443 S.E.2d 392 (1994); Small, 329 S.C. at 463, 494 S.E.2d at 842.
Ford advanced its contention that, because no reliable proof existed showing Isaac was wearing the lap belt in the 1993 Escort, any alleged defect in the lap belt design could not have proximately caused Isaacâ€™s injuries.Â  Luculently, without evidence Isaac wore the lap belt, Jamisonâ€™s defective lap belt claim even fails the â€˜but forâ€™ test for causation.Â  However, the circuit courtâ€™s exclusion of any evidence concerning a lap belt design defect was more clearly based on a preemption analysis under Geier, rather than on an analysis of proximate cause. Â 
Notwithstanding the circuit courtâ€™s rationale, this court is authorized to consider any sustaining ground pursuant to Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€) and Iâ€˜On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (â€œThe appellate court may review respondentâ€™s additional reasons and, if convinced it is proper and fair to do so, rely on them or any other reason appearing in the record to affirm the lower courtâ€™s judgment.â€).Â  Accordingly, we hereby encapsulate the entire reasoning and rationale in regard to proximate cause as an additional sustaining ground if perchance there is any issue as to the preservation of Fordâ€™s proximate cause argument.
II. Crash Tests
The circuit court excluded video crash tests of a 1995 Escort that Jamison purported were substantially similar to the collision in this case and should have been admitted.Â  Jamison complains the exclusion was error; we disagree.[6]Â Â Â  
â€œThe admission of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial judge, and absent a clear abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law, the trial courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal.â€Â  Vaught v. A.O. Hardee & Sons, Inc., 366 S.C. 475, 480, 623 S.E.2d 373, 375 (2005). Â An abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion without evidentiary support. Â Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 363 S.C. 460, 467, 611 S.E.2d 905, 908 (2005).Â  â€œTo warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice, i.e., there is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the wrongly admitted or excluded evidence.â€Â  Id.Â  
Generally, in order for an out of court experiment to be admissible, the experiment must â€œbe made under conditions and circumstances similar to those prevailing at the time of the occurrence involved in the controversy.â€Â  State v. Frazier, 357 S.C. 161, 166, 592 S.E.2d 621, 623 (2004) (quoting Weaks v. S.C. State Hwy. Depâ€™t, 250 S.C. 535, 542, 159 S.E.2d 234, 237 (1968)).Â  â€œIt
is not required that the conditions be identical with those existing at the time of the controversy; it is sufficient if there is a substantial similarity.â€Â  Id.  (quoting Weaks, 250 S.C. at 542, 159 S.E.2d at 237).Â  
Relevant evidence is evidence that tends to prove or disprove the existence of a material fact and is generally admissible.Â  Rule 401, SCRE; Rule 402, SCRE.Â  However, â€œ[t]he dictates of Rule 401 are subject to the balancing requirement of Rule 403, SCRE, which requires a court to exclude relevant evidence upon a showing that its admission would be more prejudicial than probative.â€Â  Watson ex rel. Watson v. Chapman, 343 S.C. 471, 478, 540 S.E.2d 484, 487 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Under Rule 403, SCRE, â€œalthough relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury . . . .â€Â  Moreover, â€œ[a] trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value and prejudicial effect of evidence should be reversed only in exceptional circumstances.â€Â  
State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 378, 580 S.E.2d 785, 794 (Ct. App. 2003) (citation omitted) (stating that under the abuse of discretion standard the reviewing court is â€œobligated to give great deference to the trial courtâ€™s judgmentâ€).Â  
Jamison sought to introduce the 1995 video crash tests to demonstrate the effect of impact on occupant kinematics.Â  Admittedly, the excluded video illustrated a vehicle and collision substantially similar to the 1993 Escort and accident in this case. Â However, unlike the 1993 Escort, the vehicle in the excluded video was equipped with airbags that deployed upon impact.Â  Ford maintained â€œ[i]t cannot be said that the air bag going off into the face and the chest of the dummy does not affect the dummyâ€™s occupant kinematics.â€Â  The circuit court observed that the 1995 video crash tests presented:

[o]ne of the rare occasions that I believe it covers just about every one that is mentioned in 403.Â  Clearly the danger of an unfair prejudice is there.Â  Confusion of the issue is clearly there.Â  Misleading the jury is clearly there because it makesâ€”thereâ€™s no way for testimony to undo whatâ€™s visual.

The juryâ€™s susceptibility to influences associated with viewing a crash test involving an airbag can reasonably be recognized as substantially outweighing the testsâ€™ probative value.Â  We defer to the circuit courtâ€™s judgment in this instance.Â  
III. Discovery Abuses
Jamison challenges the circuit courtâ€™s refusal to sanction Ford for alleged discovery abuses.Â  We discern no error in the circuit courtâ€™s ruling.
Pursuant to Rule 37(b)(2)(C), SCRCP, when a party fails to obey an order to provide or permit discovery, the court may â€œmake such orders in regard to the failure as are just,â€ including an order dismissing the action or proceeding, or any part thereof. Â Temple v. Tec-Fab, Inc., 370 S.C. 383, 390, 635 S.E.2d 541, 544 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing In re Anonymous Member of the S.C. Bar, 346 S.C. 177, 194, 552 S.E.2d 10, 18 (2001) (â€œ[j]udges must use their authority to make sure that abusive deposition tactics and other forms of discovery abuse do not succeed in their ultimate goal: achieving success through abuse of the discovery rules rather than by the rule of law.â€). Â Generally, â€œthe sanction should be aimed at the specific conduct of the party sanctioned and not go beyond the necessities of the situation to foreclose a decision on the merits of a case.â€ Â Griffin Grading & Clearing, Inc. v. Tire Serv. Equip. Mfg. Co., Inc., 334 S.C. 193, 198, 511 S.E.2d 716, 719 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
The imposition of sanctions is generally entrusted to the sound discretion of the trial court. Â Halverson v. Yawn, 328 S.C. 618, 620-21, 493 S.E.2d 883, 884 (Ct. App. 1997); Downey v. Dixon, 294 S.C. 42, 46, 362 S.E.2d 317, 318 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  The circuit courtâ€™s decision regarding the imposition of discovery sanctions will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Samples v. Mitchell, 329 S.C. 105, 111, 495 S.E.2d 213, 216 (Ct. App. 1997).Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
â€œIn deciding what sanction to impose for failure to disclose evidence during the discovery process, the trial court should weigh the nature of the interrogatories, the discovery posture of the case, willfulness, and the degree of prejudice.â€Â  Samples, 329 S.C. at 112, 495 S.E.2d at 216.Â  A failure to weigh the required factors demonstrates a failure to exercise discretion and amounts to an abuse of discretion.Â  Id. Â Â Â 
Here, the record indicates the circuit court considered the nature of the requests for production, the discovery posture of the case, Fordâ€™s lack of intent or willfulness, and the degree of prejudice Jamison suffered.Â  During the pre-trial hearing, the circuit court noted Jamison demonstrated no prejudice, Ford adhered to the continuing rule to supplement responses to production requests, and nothing suggested Ford knew about the evidence at issue.Â  Moreover, the record fails to substantiate that Ford either knew about or possessed the evidence in question when initially responding to Jamisonâ€™s discovery requests.Â  In fact, Ford complied with the rules of discovery by confirming that Mazda possessed the evidence and forwarding Jamisonâ€™s request to Mazda.Â  Indeed, Jamison admitted all documents in question were originally produced by Mazda.Â  Additionally, Ford satisfied the rule requiring continued supplementation of responses to interrogatories.Â  
Jamison implored the court to sanction Ford by prohibiting reference to the 1993 Escortâ€™s compliance with federal regulations.Â  The circuit court found no evidence Ford acted in bad faith with the willful disobedience or gross indifference required for a sanction that would be tantamount to default judgment.Â  See Griffin Grading & Clearing, Inc., 334 S.C. at 198-99, 511 S.E.2d at 719 (â€œWhere the sanction would be tantamount to granting a judgment by default, the moving party must show bad faith, willful disobedience or gross indifference to its rights to justify the sanction.â€).Â  Conclusively, the circuit court exercised sound discretion in refraining from the imposition of discovery abuse sanctions. 
IV. Rule 60(b), SCRCP, Motion
Jamison next argues the circuit erred in denying its Rule 60(b) motion for relief from judgment.Â  Jamison contends the advertising brochure for the European Escort provided evidence of an existing alternative design and was material to its case.Â  In addition, Jamison professes that the brochure provided a basis for sanctions against Ford for abuse of discovery.Â  We disagree. 
Generally, the decision to grant a new trial under Rule 60(b) lies within the sound discretion of the circuit court.Â  Raby Constr., L.L.P. v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 17, 594 S.E.2d 478, 482 (2005).Â  The appellate court will reverse a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding the grant or denial of a Rule 60(b) motion only if it amounts to an abuse of discretion.Â  Id. at 18, 594 S.E.2d at
482. 
A.  Newly Discovered Evidence
The circuit court may relieve a party from a final judgment where â€œnewly discovered evidence which by due diligence could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial under Rule 59(b).â€Â  Rule 60(b)(2), SCRCP.Â  â€œA party seeking to set aside a judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b) has the burden of presenting evidence entitling him to the requested relief.â€Â  Perry v. Heirs at Law of Gadsden, 357 S.C. 42, 46, 590 S.E.2d 502, 504 (Ct. App. 2003). Â To obtain a new trial based on newly discovered evidence, a movant must establish that the newly discovered evidence: (1) will probably change the result if a new trial is granted; (2) has been discovered since the trial; (3) could not have been discovered before the trial; (4) is material to the issue; and (5) is not merely cumulative or impeaching.Â  Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 217, 612 S.E.2d 456, 459 (Ct. App. 2005) (citation omitted).Â  Courts have found evidence is not newly discovered evidence for the purposes of Rule 60(b)(2) where the evidence was (1) known to the party at the time of trial, and (2) in the partyâ€™s possession. Â Id. at 218, 612 S.E.2d at 459.Â  In addition, Rule 60(b)(2) allows the court to grant a new trial only if the newly discovered evidence could not have been discovered by due diligence prior to trial.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary defines â€œdue diligenceâ€ as â€œ[t]he diligence reasonably expected from, and ordinarily exercised by, a person who seeks to satisfy a legal requirement or to discharge an obligation.â€Â  468 (7th ed. 1999). Â Furthermore, exclusion of testimony that would be merely cumulative or impeaching does not constitute error. Â See Gamble v. International Paper Realty Corp. of South Carolina, 323 S.C. 367, 474 S.E.2d 438 (1996) (ruling that where excluded testimony was merely cumulative there was no error).
In the case at bar, the circuit court ruled the brochure advertising the European Escort that Jamison advanced as newly discovered evidence would not likely change the result in a new trial and was merely cumulative.Â  As a threshold requirement, before the brochure or any test regarding the European Escort could be admissible, Jamison had to demonstrate the European Escort was substantially similar to the 1993 Escort at issue.Â  See State v. Frazier, 357 S.C. 161, 166, 592 S.E.2d 621, 623 (2004) (holding an out of court experiment will only be admissible if proven to be substantially similar to the occurrence involved in the controversy).Â  Jamison could not prove the European Escort was substantially similar to the 1993 Escort.Â  Concomitantly, Ford provided an affidavit stating the vehicles differed significantly in structural design.Â  
Jamison urged that the brochure constituted new evidence of a feasible alternative designâ€”a critical and material element of its defective design claim.Â  The circuit court noted, however, that Jamison had presented evidence of a feasible alternative design at trial. Â Jamison submitted a 1987 Volkswagen as an example of an effective passive restraint system with a seat pan that could successfully restrain the lower torso in an accident like the one in this case.Â  Thus, the brochure, as evidence of a feasible alternative design, albeit one Ford employed, is merely cumulative of evidence introduced at trial.Â  Jamisonâ€™s potential use of the brochure for impeachment of Fordâ€™s witness does not support granting the Rule 60(b) motion.Â  See Lanier, 364 S.C. at 217, 612 S.E.2d at 459. 
B.  Fraud, Misrepresentation, or Other Misconduct
Rule 60(b)(3), SCRCP authorizes the circuit court to relieve a party from a final judgment where the party demonstrates â€œfraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct of an adverse party.â€Â  In South Carolina, in order for a party to be entitled to relief based on fraud, the moving party must demonstrate extrinsic fraud.Â  Raby Constr., LLP v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 20-21, 594 S.E.2d 478, 484 (2005); Hagy v. Pruitt, 339 S.C. 425, 431, 529 S.E.2d 714, 717 (2000) (â€œA judgment may be set aside on the ground of fraud only if the fraud is â€˜extrinsicâ€™ and not â€˜intrinsic.â€™â€).Â  Fraud is extrinsic when it is collateral to the issues tried in a case and effectively deprives the litigant of a fair hearing or the opportunity to present its case.Â  Id. (citing Â Hilton Head Ctr. of S.C., Inc. v. Pub. Serv, Commâ€™n of S. C., 294 S.C. 9, 362 S.E.2d 176 (1987); Mr. G. v. Mrs. G., 320 S.C. 305, 465 S.E.2d 101 (Ct. App. 1995). Â â€œRelief is granted for extrinsic fraud on the theory that because the fraud prevented a party from fully exhibiting and trying his case, there has never been a real contest before the court on the subject matter of the action.â€ Â Chewning v. Ford Motor Co., 354 S.C. 72, 81, 579 S.E.2d 605, 610 (2003) (citing Hilton Head, 294 S.C. at 11, 362 S.E.2d at 177). Â On the other hand, intrinsic fraud is fraud presented and considered at the trial. Â Hagy, 339 S.C. at 431, 529 S.E.2d at 484 (citing Evans v. Gunter, 366 S.E.2d 44, 294 S.C. 525 (Ct. App. 1988)).Â  Intrinsic fraud misleads a court in determining issues and induces the court to find for the party perpetrating the fraud.Â  Chewning, 354 S.C. at 81, 579 S.C.2d at 610 (citing Hilton Head, 294 S.C. at 11, 362 S.E.2d at 177).
Jamison maintains Ford engaged in fraudulent conduct by withholding the brochure; consequently, the circuit court should grant relief from judgment.Â  The record fails to substantiate Jamisonâ€™s allegations that Ford intentionally withheld documents.Â  Moreover, the assertion that a party failed to disclose documents generally amounts to intrinsic rather than extrinsic fraud.Â  Raby Constr., 358 S.C. at 19, 594 S.E.2d at 483.
Accordingly, Jamison was not entitled to a Rule 60(b) relief from judgment on either newly discovered evidence or fraud. 
CONCLUSION
We hold that the Safety Act, FMVSS 208, and Geier prohibit a state common law tort action based on the choice of design of a passive vehicle passenger restraint system.Â  We rule that a state common tort action is permitted if bottomed and premised on defects in design and/or implementation of the chosen restraint system.Â  
Finally, we place our imprimatur and approbation upon the arbitraments of the circuit court in regard to:Â  (1) the exclusion of Jamisonâ€™s expert testimony in reference to the manual lap belt; (2) the disallowance of video crash tests of the 1995 Escort with a driver side airbag; (3) the denial of Jamisonâ€™s motion for sanctions; and (4) the rejection of Jamisonâ€™s motion for relief from judgment.Â  
Accordingly, the rulings and orders of the circuit court are 
 AFFIRMED.
 KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Jamison additionally averred that Ford failed to provide adequate warnings about proper use of the restraint system.Â  However, this appeal does not involve claims regarding whether any warnings were inadequate.Â  
[3]Â  Jamisonâ€™s attorney received the crash test documents from a plaintiffâ€™s attorney involved in other litigation with Ford.
[4] Field preemption occurs when federal law so occupies a field that state courts are prevented from asserting jurisdiction.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary, 612 (6th ed. 1990).Â  Field preemption is not implicated in the instant case.
[5] Components other than a belt provided lower torso restraint. 
[6] Because of our disposition of this issue, we decline to address Fordâ€™s contention that Jamison waived this issue by failing to properly challenge the legal grounds on appeal.Â

description: Jerry Thomas appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order terminating his lease agreement with Edward Bowers.  Thomas contends: (1) there was insufficient notice to terminate the lease agreement; (2) the lease could not be terminated based on the tardy payment of the June rent; and (3) the circuit court erred in denying his request for a jury trial. text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        
          
            
              
Edward P. Bowers Respondent,
v.
Jerry D. Thomas  Appellant.
              
            
          
        
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball, III, Master In Equity

Opinion No. 4221
Heard March 6, 2007 â€“ Filed March 19, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Deborah Harrison Sheffield, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Philip J. Corson, of Lake Wylie, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Jerry Thomas appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order terminating his lease agreement with Edward Bowers.Â  Thomas contends: (1) there was insufficient notice to terminate the lease agreement; (2) the lease could not be terminated based on the tardy payment of the June rent; and (3) the circuit court erred in denying his request for a jury trial. Â We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On March 1, 2005, Bowers and Thomas entered into a written rental agreement governed by the South Carolina Residential Landlord and Tenant Act (â€œthe RLTAâ€).Â  Rent was due and payable in advance on the first day of each month.Â  The rental agreement gave Thomas the option to purchase the property, provided Thomas was not in default at the time.Â  The agreement provided:Â  

LANDLORDâ€™S REMEDIES.Â  If Tenant defaults in the payment of rent, or any other item to be paid by Tenant under this Lease, and that default is not cured within ten (10) days, except for the payment of rent, after written notice of default by Landlord to Tenant, it being agreed that rent shall be due and payable without notice, Landlord may re-enter and take possession of the Premises and remove all persons and property from the Premises, and at its option terminate this Lease, and shall have such rights as are available under South Carolina law.Â  Tenant and Landlord agree that if rent is not paid within ten (10) days of its due date, this Lease and the attached Option Agreement shall both terminate immediately without further notice.Â  

(Emphasis in original).Â  
In June 2005, Thomas failed to pay the June rent at the time it was due.Â  After receiving written notice of his June default and Bowersâ€™ intent to terminate the lease, Thomas delivered a check for the rent to Bowersâ€™ attorney.Â  The check, dated June 23, 2005, was returned to Thomasâ€™ lawyer.Â  Thomasâ€™ lawyer then mailed the check back to Bowersâ€™ counsel; however, it was never received, and the June rent remained unpaid.Â  
Rent payments continued to be late.Â  The July 2005 rent was not paid until the fourteenth of the month.Â  On July 15, 2005, Bowers gave Thomas written notice of nonpayment of rent when due and his intention to terminate the lease agreement if rent was not paid within ten days from the due date.Â  Specifically, the notice stated:

If you do not pay your rent on time this is your notice.Â  If you do not pay your rent within 10 days of the due date, the landlord can start to have you evicted.Â  You will get no other notice as long as you live in this rental unit. Â 

The August 2005 rent was not paid within ten days of its due date.Â  On August 11, 2005, the magistrate issued an order and rule to show cause, ordering Thomas to either vacate the premises, or appear and show cause why he should not be evicted.Â  On August 12, 2005, Thomas delivered a check to Bowersâ€™ attorney with the mutual agreement that such acceptance would not constitute a waiver of any default.Â  
A bench trial was scheduled for August 23, 2005.Â  Four working days before the trial, Thomas requested a jury trial. Â The magistrate denied the request as untimely, but rescheduled the bench trial.Â  After the bench trial on September 1, 2005, the magistrate ordered Thomasâ€™s eviction and payment of all accrued rent.Â  Thomas appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the magistrateâ€™s order.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section 18-7-170 of the South Carolina Code (1985) articulates the standard of review to be applied by the circuit court in an appeal of a magistrateâ€™s judgment:Â  

Upon hearing the appeal, the appellate court shall give judgment according to the justice of the case, without regard to technical errors and defects which do not affect the merits.Â  In giving judgment, the court may affirm or reverse the judgment of the court below, in whole or in part, as to any or all the parties and for errors of law or fact.

See also Hadfield v. Gilchrist, 343 S.C. 88, 92-93, 538 S.E.2d 268, 270 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
While the Circuit Court maintains a broad scope of review, our standard is more limited:


[T]he Court of Appeals will presume that an affirmance by a Circuit Court of a magistrateâ€™s judgment was made upon the merits where the testimony is sufficient to sustain the judgment of the magistrate and there are no facts that show the affirmance was influenced by an error of law. 

Burns v. Wannamaker, 281 S.C. 352, 357, 315 S.E.2d 179, 182 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Specifically, â€œ[i]n ejectment proceedings first heard in magistrateâ€™s court, the Court of Appeals is without jurisdiction to reverse the findings of fact of the circuit court if there is any supporting evidence.â€Â  Vacation Time of Hilton Head Island, Inc. v. Kiwi Corp., 280 S.C. 232, 233, 312 S.E.2d 20, 21 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  â€œUnless we find an error of law, we will affirm the judgeâ€™s holding if there are any facts supporting his decision.â€Â  Hadfield, 343 S.C. at 94, 538 S.E.2d at 271.
However, as recognized in Hadfield, the Court of Appeals still retains de novo review of whether the facts show the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance was controlled or affected by errors of law.Â  Hadfield at 92-93, 53 S.E.2d at 270.Â  Our Supreme Court, in Stanford v. Cudd, 93 S.C. 367, 370, 76 S.E. 986, 987 (1913), held that where the testimony is sufficient to sustain a judgment of the magistrateâ€™s court, and it is affirmed on appeal to the circuit court, this court will assume the circuit court affirmed the judgment on the merits, in the absence of facts showing the affirmance was controlled or affected by errors of law.
LAW/ANALYSIS
A.Â  Default 
Thomas contends the circuit court erred in finding there was legally sufficient notice to justify termination of his lease.Â  We disagree.Â  
Section 27-40-710 of the South Carolina Code (2007) governs a landlordâ€™s remedies in situations where a tenant fails to pay rent when due.Â  In pertinent part, section 27-40-710(B) states:Â  

If rent is unpaid when due and the tenant fails to pay rent within five days from the date due or the tenant is in violation of section 27-40-540, the landlord may terminate the rental agreement provided the landlord has given the tenant written notice of nonpayment and his intention to terminate the rental agreement if the rent is not paid within that period. Â The landlordâ€™s obligation to provide notice under this section is satisfied for any lease term after the landlord has given one such notice to the tenant or if the notice is contained in conspicuous language in a written rental agreement. Â The written notice requirement upon the landlord under this subsection shall be considered to have been complied with if the rental agreement contains the following or a substantially equivalent provision:
  
â€œIF YOU DO NOT PAY YOUR RENT ON TIME
This is your notice. If you do not pay your rent within five days of the due date, the landlord can start to have you evicted. You will get no other notice as long as you live in this rental unit.â€
  
The presence of this provision in the rental agreement fully satisfies the â€œwritten noticeâ€ requirement under this subsection and applies to a month-to-month tenancy following the specified lease term in the original rental agreement.

(Emphasis in original).Â  
Thomas contends the circuit court erred in finding that Bowers gave proper notice of non-compliance with the lease agreement, under section 27-40-710(B).Â  In this instance, notice was provided not by â€œconspicuous languageâ€ in the partiesâ€™ lease agreement, but by the July 15, 2005 letter mailed notifying Thomas that any subsequent nonpayment would result in eviction.Â  This letter indubitably satisfies the language contained in section 27-40-710(B).Â  Despite receiving this notice in July, Thomas failed to pay his August rent in a timely manner.Â  In fact, the August rent was not paid until after the magistrate issued the rule to show cause.Â  
Because a landlordâ€™s obligation to provide notice is satisfied for any lease term after the landlord has given one such notice to the tenant, the landlord was not required to furnish any separate or additional written notice to Thomas in order to commence proceedings in August for nonpayment of rent when due.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-40-710(B) (2007).Â  Â Accordingly, the circuit court did not err in finding there was sufficient notice to terminate the lease after the late payment of the August rent.Â  
Thomas devotes a great deal of his brief to the position that the language in the lease agreement was not â€œbold and conspicuousâ€ as required by the statute.Â  However, we need not reach this issue because Thomas had sufficient notice under section 27-40-710(B) from the July 2005 letter of the consequences if he failed to pay his rent in a timely manner.Â  
Additionally, Thomas argues the lease agreement should not have been terminated based on the June rent because his rent check was returned to him after he delivered it to Bowersâ€™ attorney.Â  However, this argument is flawed as the lease was not terminated based on Thomasâ€™s failure to pay the June rent, but rather was terminated based on his failure to pay the August rent after the notice was sent in July.Â  The June check was dated June 23, 2005, twenty-two days after its due date.Â  This check was lost, and as of the date of the circuit courtâ€™s order, payment for June rent has not been made and Thomas is still liable for the June 2005 rent. 
B.Â  Jury Trial 
Thomas contends the circuit court erred in denying his request for a jury trial.Â  We disagree.Â  
Initially, this issue has not been preserved for our review.Â  Bowers never objected to the magistrateâ€™s ruling concerning a jury trial.Â  An issue not raised to and ruled upon by the court is not preserved for appeal.Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).
Furthermore, Thomas has waived this issue.Â  If an order deprives a party of a mode of trial to which that party is entitled as a matter of right, the order is
immediately appealable and failure to do so forever bars appellate review.Â  Flagstar Corp. v. Royal Surplus Lines, 341 S.C. 68, 72, 533 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2000); Foggie v. CSX Transp., Inc., 315 S.C. 17, 23, 431 S.E.2d 587, 590 (1993).Â  Because Thomas failed to immediately appeal his denial of a jury trial, he is barred from raising this issue on appeal.
Moreover, this issue fails on the merits.Â  Rule 11(b), SCMCR states that â€œIf either party wants a jury trial it must be requested in writing at least five working days prior to the date set for trial.â€Â  The Notice of Hearing shows the trial was set for August 23, 2005.Â  Thomasâ€™s written request for a jury trial was not submitted to the magistrate until August 17, 2005, only four working days prior to trial.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not err in finding Thomasâ€™s request untimely and affirming the denial of a jury trial.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the above analysis, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.
