THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Brandi Rhodes, Respondent,
        v.
        Benson Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc. d/b/a Benson Chrysler-Plymouth Dodge, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville CountyÂ 
  Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Circuit
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 4222
  Withdrawn, Substituted, and Refiled on May
  31, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Bradford N. Martin, Laura W.H. Teer, Lora E. Collins, and Robin
          Foster, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Lane W. Davis, of Greenville, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â 
  Benson Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc. appeals the denial of its motion to compel
  arbitration.Â  We affirm.[1]Â 
  We hold a party waives its right to enforce an arbitration provision when it
  delays in demanding arbitration and engages in extensive discovery resulting in
  prejudice to the party opposing arbitration.Â  
I.
In
  April 2005, Brandi Rhodes sued Benson Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc. (Benson) for
  breach of contract in connection with the purchase of a vehicle.[2]Â  Benson answered,
  pleading the contract contained an arbitration provision that encompassed Rhodesâ€™ allegations.Â  Benson, however, did not promptly pursue arbitration, opting instead
  to engage in extensive discovery.Â  Benson and Rhodes exchanged written
  interrogatories and requests for production.Â  Benson also noticed and took five
  depositions.Â  Benson sought the circuit courtâ€™s assistance in executing
  out-of-state subpoenas, which the circuit court granted.Â  The circuit court
  heard two motions for protective orders.Â  
In
  February 2006, ten months after Rhodes initiated this action, Benson filed a
  motion to compel arbitration.Â  Rhodes opposed Bensonâ€™s attempt to resurrect its
  right to arbitrate under the contract.Â  Rhodes argued Benson waived its right
  to compel arbitration by participating in significant discovery before pursuing
  arbitration.Â  The circuit court agreed with Rhodes, and denied Bensonâ€™s motion
  to compel arbitration.Â  It further appears that the case was scheduled for
  trial before the circuit court ruled on Bensonâ€™s motion to compel arbitration.Â 
  Benson appeals.
II.
â€œ[D]etermining whether a party waived its right to arbitrate is a
  legal conclusion subject to de novo review; nevertheless, the circuit judgeâ€™s
  factual findings underlying that conclusion will not be overruled if there is
  any evidence reasonably supporting them.â€Â  Liberty Builders, Inc. v. Horton,
  336 S.C. 658, 664-65, 521 S.E.2d 749, 753 (Ct. App. 1999). 
III.
South Carolina favors arbitration.Â  Gen. Equip. & Supply Co. v. Keller Rigging &
  Constr., Inc., 344 S.C. 553, 556, 544 S.E.2d 643, 645 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The
  right to enforce an arbitration clause, however, may be waived.Â  Liberty
    Builders, Inc. v. Horton, 336 S.C. 658, 665, 521 S.E.2d 749, 753 (Ct. App.
  1999).Â  â€œIn order to establish waiver, a party must show prejudice through an
  undue burden caused by delay in demanding arbitration.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThere is
  no set rule as to what constitutes a waiver of the right to arbitrate; the
  question depends on the facts of each case.â€Â  Id. 
Generally,
  the factors our courts consider to determine if a party waived its right to
  compel arbitration are: (1) whether a substantial length of time transpired
  between the commencement of the action and the commencement of the motion to
  compel arbitration; (2) whether the party requesting arbitration engaged in
  extensive discovery before moving to compel arbitration; and (3) whether the
  non-moving party was prejudiced by the delay in seeking arbitration.Â  These
  factors, of course, are not mutually exclusive, as one factor may be
  inextricably connected to, and influenced by, the others. 
Thus, a
  party may waive its right to compel arbitration if a substantial length of time
  transpires between the commencement of the action and the commencement of the
  motion to compel arbitration.Â  What is â€œa substantial length of timeâ€ varies
  from one case to the next, depending on the extent of discovery conducted and
  the corresponding presence or absence of prejudice to the party opposing
  arbitration.Â  Compare Deloitte & Touche, LLP v. Unisys Corp.,
  358 S.C. 179, 184, 594 S.E.2d 523, 526 (Ct. App. 2004) (finding a
  five-and-a-half year period where the parties â€œconducted a significant amount of discovery, resulting in
  the production of thousands of documentsâ€ demonstrated waiver); and Evans v. Accent Manufactured Homes,
    Inc., 352 S.C. 544, 548, 575 S.E.2d 74, 75-76 (Ct. App. 2003) (finding a
  nineteen month period where the
  parties exchanged written interrogatories, requests to produce, and the party
  requesting arbitration took two depositions demonstrated waiver); and Liberty Builders, 336 S.C. at 666, 521
  S.E.2d at 753-54 (finding a two-and-a-half year period where the parties sought assistance from
  the court on approximately forty occasions demonstrated waiver); with Tolerâ€™s Cove Homeowners Assâ€™n, Inc. v.
    Trident Constr. Co., 355 S.C. 605, 612, 586 S.E.2d 581, 585 (2003) (finding
  a thirteen month period where
  discovery was â€œvery limited in nature and the parties had not availed
  themselves of the courtâ€™s assistance,â€ and â€œRespondent had not held any
  depositions,â€ did not demonstrate
  waiver); and Rich v. Walsh, 357 S.C. 64, 67, 590 S.E.2d 506, 507
  (Ct. App. 2003) (finding a thirteen month period where â€œ[l]imited discovery was conductedâ€ and the party
  requesting arbitration took one deposition lasting fifteen minutes did not demonstrate waiver); and Gen.
    Equip., 344 S.C. at 557, 544 S.E.2d at 645 (finding a period of less than
  eight months where the
  â€œlitigation consisted of routine administrative matters and limited discovery
  which did not involve the taking of depositions or extensive interrogatoriesâ€ did not establish waiver).
To establish prejudice, the non-moving party must show something
  more than â€œmere inconvenience.â€Â  Evans, 352 S.C. at 550, 575 S.E.2d at
  76-77.Â  To ascertain whether the non-moving party was prejudiced, our courts
  often examine whether the party requesting arbitration took â€œadvantage of the
  judicial system by engaging in discovery.â€Â  Id. at 548, 575 S.E.2d at
  76.Â  This inquiry, however, is just part of a broader, common sense approach
  our courts take to determine whether a motion to compel arbitration should be
  granted or denied: (1) if the parties conduct little or no discovery, then the
  party seeking arbitration has not taken â€œadvantage of the judicial system,â€ prejudice
  will likely not exist, and the law would favor arbitration; (2) if the parties
  conduct significant discovery, then the party seeking arbitration has taken
  â€œadvantage of the judicial system,â€ prejudice will likely exist, and the law
  would disfavor arbitration.Â  Of course, cases do not always fit neatly into
  clearly defined categories, which is why our law resists a formulaic approach
  and motions to compel arbitration are resolved only after a fact-intensive
  inquiry.Â  Accordingly, each case turns on its particular facts.Â Â  
This case, we believe, falls between the General Equipment line of cases (Tolerâ€™s Cove and Rich) and the Liberty Builders line of cases (Evans and Deloitte).Â  Because Benson sought
  arbitration less than a year after Rhodes brought suit, General Equipment suggests that a substantial length of time may not have transpired to warrant
  waiver.Â  Indeed, as cited above, there is precedent where arbitration was
  compelled with an even greater length of time between the commencement of the action
  and the commencement of the motion to compel arbitration.Â  See Tolerâ€™s
    Cove, 355 S.C. at 612, 586 S.E.2d at 585 (finding a thirteen month period
  did not demonstrate waiver); Rich, 357 S.C. at 72, 590 S.E.2d at 507
  (finding a thirteen month period did not demonstrate waiver).Â  What
  distinguishes this case from the General Equipment line of cases,
  however, is the extensive discovery engaged in by Rhodes and especially Benson,
  as well as the fact that the
  trial was imminent.Â  
Benson and Rhodes exchanged written interrogatories and requests
  to produce.Â  Benson also noticed and took five depositions.[3]Â  Furthermore,
  before the circuit court ruled on Bensonâ€™s tardy motion to compel arbitration,
  the chief administrative judge set the case on the trial docket for an upcoming
  term of court.Â  The parties completed virtually all discovery before Benson moved to compel arbitration.Â  The extent of discovery, in conjunction
  with the status of the case on the trial docket, provides a direct nexus to the
  presence and degree of prejudice sustained by Rhodes, the party opposing
  arbitration.Â  We are persuaded that under the facts presented here Benson
  waived its right to compel arbitration.Â  
IV.
The record amply supports the findings of the learned special
  circuit court judge.Â  Benson, with full knowledge of its right to arbitrate
  this dispute, cannot invoke and enjoy the full benefits of discovery and then
  belatedly assert a right to arbitrate at the eleventh hour with the case
  approaching trial.Â  The order of the circuit court denying the motion to compel
  arbitration is 
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  According to the complaint, Rhodes agreed to
  purchase a properly-titled, undamaged 2001 Dodge Durango from Benson, and not
  the stolen, damaged 1999 Dodge Durango Rhodes received from Benson.
[3]Â  Depositions entail more than â€œroutine administrative
  matters,â€Â  Gen. Equip., 344 S.C. at 557, 544 S.E.2d at 645, and could
  not be considered â€œlimited discoveryâ€ in any sense of the phrase.Â  Certainly,
  taking five depositions was more than a â€œmere inconvenienceâ€ to Rhodes.Â  Depositions involve substantial time, effort, and money, all of which could have
  been avoided if Benson had pursued arbitration earlier.

title: Arcadian Shores v. Cromer
description: Arcadian Shores Single Family Homeowners' Association, Inc. (the Association) appeals the master's refusal to issue a permanent injunction requiring Miriam Cromer to comply with certain restrictive covenants.  We held the more specific restrictive covenenants were never properly instituted, and the more general restrictive covenants did not prevent Cromer's actions.  Further, the Association had abandoned its right to enforce certain covenants.  We affirmed and upheld the award of Cromer's costs of complying with a temporary injucnction.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Arcadian Shores Single Family Homeowners Association, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
Miriam R. Cromer, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 4223
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 26, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
C. Scott Masel, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant
Robin S. Cromer, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.: Arcadian Shores Single Family Homeownersâ€™ Association, Inc., (the Association) appeals the masterâ€™s refusal to issue a permanent injunction requiring Miriam R. Cromer to comply with certain restrictive covenants.Â  The Association contends the master erred in (1) refusing to find Cromer had actual or constructive knowledge of the 1985 Regulations; (2) failing to hold Cromerâ€™s motor home violated the intent and purpose of the 1965 Declaration; (3) finding Cromerâ€™s motor home did not violate the plain language of the 1985 Regulations; (4) holding the Association abandoned its right to enforce the restrictive covenants; (5) denying its claim for injunctive relief; and (6) awarding Cromer the costs of complying with a temporary injunction.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On March 11, 1965, Ocean Lakes Investment Company (Developer) adopted and recorded a declaration of restrictions (the 1965 Declaration) applying to lots 5 through 97 of the Arcadian Shores Subdivision (the Subdivision).Â  The 1965 Declaration provides, in pertinent part:

4. . . . No building, outbuilding, addition, or fencing shall be constructed without first submitting plans and specifications to and obtaining the written approval of the plans by the Developer, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld.
. . . . 
7. . . Lot owners will comply with such reasonable regulations as the Developer may make as to the location of fixtures or appliances . . . and as to parking or storage of commercial vehicles, boats or machinery on the premises.
8. Except as incidental and necessary to permanent building construction . . . no mobile home, temporary structure or garage apartment shall be erected upon the lot.

On June 14, 1982, the Developerâ€™s trustee executed and recorded a corrective quit-claim deed in favor of the Association, purporting to convey all of its rights in the Subdivision, particularly the following:

All of the [Developerâ€™s] rights under recorded restrictions applicable to [the Subdivision] to enforce any and all such restrictions . . . to approve or disapprove plans and specifications . . . to make regulations permitted by the Subdivision restrictions and to enforce same . . . .[2]Â  

On January 15, 1985, the Association attempted to enact a set of regulations applicable to the Subdivision (the 1985 Regulations).[3]Â  The 1985 Regulations specify, in detail, the applicable fencing limits and plainly prohibit motor homes and travel trailers from being parked where they are visible from the street.Â  The 1985 Regulations were also recorded.Â Â  
On March 24, 2000, the homeowners in the Subdivision elected to create a Special Tax District.Â  Although the Association assigned and delegated many of its rights and duties to the Special Tax District, it retained all of its rights to enforce recorded restrictions, approve or disapprove plans and specifications, and make regulations.Â Â  Â 
On July 2, 2003, Cromer obtained title to Lot 96 in the Subdivision.Â  After she purchased Lot 96, she sought to park a motor home and trailer on the property.Â  The motor home and trailer together were seventy feet long.Â  In addition, she submitted plans and specifications to the Association in order to get approval for a fence and other building modifications on the property.Â  The plans called for a three foot high masonry lattice wall in the front yard of Lot 96. Â The Association approved these plans.Â  However, Cromer built a three foot high solid stucco wall instead.Â  
On January 23, 2004, the Association filed a complaint against Cromer, seeking to enjoin her from parking her motor home in a place where it would be visible from the street and to require Cromer to remove her fence.Â  Cromer answered, denying her motor home or fence violated the applicable restrictive covenants.Â  The Association sought and obtained a temporary injunction requiring Cromer to comply with the 1985 Regulations with respect to her motor home.Â  As a precondition to issuing this injunction, the circuit court required the Association submit a $10,000 surety bond to reimburse Cromer should the injunction later be overruled.Â  
After an order of reference, the master held a hearing and ultimately denied the Associationâ€™s requests regarding both the motor home and the fence.Â  Of consequence to the present appeal, the master made the following findings and conclusions: (1) the 1985 Regulations were not valid because they were not properly signed, acknowledged, or indexed; (2) the 1965 Declaration does not prohibit Cromerâ€™s motor home; (3) the Association abandoned its right to approve of fencing; and (4) Cromer should receive $9,000 of the surety bond for reimbursement of expenses associated with the temporary injunction.Â  This appeal followed. Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is in equity.â€Â  Seabrook Is. Prop. Owners Assâ€™n v. Marshland Trust, Inc., 358 S.C. 655, 661, 596 S.E.2d 380, 383 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In equitable actions, the appellate court may make findings of fact in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Grosshuesch v. Cramer, 367 S.C. 1, 4, 623 S.E.2d 833, 834 (2005).Â  However, the appellate court is not required to ignore the findings of the master when the master was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Siau v. Kassel, 369 S.C. 631, 638, 632 S.E.2d 888, 892 (Ct. App. 2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. The Motor Home
The Association contends the master erred in refusing to order Cromer to comply with the 1985 Regulations regarding the parking of her motor home and trailer.Â  Specifically, the Association argues (1) Cromer had actual or constructive notice of the 1985 Regulations; (2) the 1985 Regulations prohibit the parking of Cromerâ€™s mobile home in an area visible from the street; (3) alternatively, the motor home violated the intent and purpose of the 1965 Declaration; (4) the Association did not waive its right to enforce the motor home restrictions; and (5) as a consequence of the above, the master erred in refusing to issue the injunction and finding Cromer entitled to $9,000 of the surety bond.
A. The Law of the Case
We recognize the master ruled the 1985 Regulations were invalid because they were improperly signed, acknowledged, and indexed.Â  While the Association appealed the issue of whether the Association properly indexed the 1985 Regulations, nothing in the Associationâ€™s appellate brief addresses the issue of whether the master erred in finding the 1985 Regulations were not validly signed or acknowledged.Â  Because the Association did not appeal this ruling, it is the law of the case.Â  See ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 472 (1997) (recognizing an unappealed finding of the master, right or wrong, is the law of the case and should not be considered by this court).Â  
In addition, based on this conclusion, we need not address the issue of whether Cromer had actual or constructive notice of the 1985 Regulations, whether the 1985 Regulations prohibited the parking of the motor home, or whether the Association waived its right to enforce the motor home restriction.Â  See Anderson v. Short, 323 S.C. 522, 525, 476 S.E.2d 475, 477 (1996) (holding when a decision is based on more than one ground, the appellate court will affirm unless the appellant appeals all grounds because the unappealed ground will become the law of the case).Â  Accordingly, we proceed to consider whether the 1965 Declaration, standing alone, precludes the parking of Cromerâ€™s motor home in an area visible from the street.
B. The 1965 Restrictions
The Association claims the 1965 Restrictions prohibit the parking of Cromerâ€™s motor home in an area visible from the street.Â  We disagree.
â€œRestrictive covenants are contractual in nature.â€Â  Hardy v. Aiken, 369 S.C. 160, 166, 631 S.E.2d 539, 542 (2006). Â The language in a restrictive covenant shall be construed according to the plain and ordinary meaning attributed to it at the time of execution.Â Â  Seabrook, 358 S.C. at 661, 596 S.E.2d at 383.Â  â€œA restriction on the use of property must be created in express terms or by plain and unmistakable implication and all such restrictions are to be strictly construed, with all doubts resolved in favor of the free use of the property.â€Â  Hamilton v. CCM, Inc., 274 S.C. 152, 157, 263 S.E.2d 378, 380 (1980) (citations omitted).Â  The court may not limit a restriction, nor will a restriction be enlarged or extended by construction or implication beyond the clear meaning of its terms, even to accomplish what it may be thought the parties would have desired had a situation which later developed been foreseen by them at the time when the restriction was written.Â  Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 4, 498 S.E.2d 862, 864 (1998) (citations and quotations omitted).
The Association points to the following provisions of the 1965 Declaration in arguing it prohibits the parking of motor homes in an area visible from the street:

7. . . Lot owners will comply with such reasonable regulations as the Developer may make as to the location of fixtures or appliances . . . and as to parking or storage of commercial vehicles, boats or machinery on the premises.
8. Except as incidental and necessary to permanent building construction . . . no mobile home, temporary structure or garage apartment shall be erected upon the lot.

The first provision gives the Developer the power to enact regulations with respect to the parking or storage of commercial vehicles, boats, or machinery.Â  Assuming Cromerâ€™s motor home is a commercial vehicle or machinery, this provision does not contain any affirmative prohibition or limitation on its parking or storage.Â  
With respect to the second provision, the Association contends motor homes were largely unknown at the date of execution of the 1965 Declaration and the prohibition on erecting a mobile home shows an intent or purpose to regulate the parking of a motor home.Â  While the Supreme Court of South Carolina initially agreed with this contention in Nance v. Waldrop, 258 S.C. 69, 187 S.E.2d 226 (1972), it subsequently rejected that line of thinking in Taylor, which overruled Nance.
In Nance, restrictions adopted in 1938 provided, in pertinent part: â€œNo house shall be erected thereon [on any lot] costing less than Four Thousand Five Hundred ($4,500.00) Dollars.â€Â  258 S.C. at 71, 187 S.E.2d at 227.Â  A subsequent purchaser placed his mobile home on the lot, and his neighbors sought an injunction enforcing the covenant.Â  Id. at 71-72, 187 S.E.2d at 227.Â  The master and circuit court held the mobile home violated the restriction and issued an injunction.Â  Id. at 72, 187 S.E.2d at 227.
On appeal, the Supreme Court noted the mobile home had been â€œvirtually unknownâ€ at the time the covenant was adopted.Â  Id. at 72, 187 S.E.2d at 228.Â  The Court ultimately concluded â€œ[t]he circumstances surrounding the inception of the restrictions and the developments subsequent thereto enforce the argument that the restrictions as drawn
were designed and intended to prevent uses such as the defendant is making of his lot.â€Â  Id. at 74-75, 187 S.E.2d at 229.
In Taylor, a restrictive covenant provided, in relevant part: â€œNo residence to cost less than $10,000.00 shall be erected on said lots . . . .â€Â  332 S.C. at 3, 498 S.E.2d at 863.Â  To prevent defendant from placing mobile homes on his lots, his neighbors sought an injunction pursuant to this covenant.Â  Id.Â  This court reversed the masterâ€™s refusal to grant the injunction, and the Supreme Court granted certiorari.Â  Id.Â  The Supreme Court questioned â€œhow the parties in Nance could have intended to prohibit mobile homes which were non-existent when the restrictive covenant was draftedâ€ and thereby overruled Nance.Â  Id. at 4, 498 S.E.2d at 864.Â  In addition, the Court explained: â€œHere, the restrictive covenant was written in the 1960s when mobile homes were prevalent. Â Therefore, if the grantor had wanted to restrict mobile homes, he could have done so.â€Â  Id. at 5, 498 S.E.2d at 864.
Applying Taylor, we hold the Developer did not intend to prohibit the parking of a motor home when it adopted the 1965 Declaration.Â  Moreover, because the 1985 Regulations are not valid, no provision prohibits Cromer from parking her motor home on her property.Â  Therefore, we hold the master did not err in refusing to grant the Associationâ€™s injunction.Â  Because of this conclusion, we also affirm the masterâ€™s decision with respect to the surety bond.
II. The Fencing
The Association maintains the master erred in refusing to order Cromer to tear down her fence.Â  In particular, the Association asserts (1) Cromer had actual or constructive notice of the Associationâ€™s right to approve of fencing; (2) the Association did not waive this right; and (3) as a consequence, the master erred in failing to grant the injunction.Â  We find it necessary only to address the issue of whether the Association waived its right to approve of Cromerâ€™s fence.
A. Waiver
The Association contends the master erred in holding it waived its right to approve of fencing.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we reiterate our holding that the master found the 1985 Regulations were invalid and this ruling is the law of the case.Â  As a result, we consider only the 1965 Declaration in determining whether the Association waived its right.Â Â  The 1965 Declaration provides, in relevant part:

No building, outbuilding, addition, or fencing shall be constructed without first submitting plans and specifications to and obtaining the written approval of the plans by the Developer, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld.

Waiver has been defined as the intentional relinquishment of a known right.Â  Gibbs v. Kimbrell, 311 S.C. 261, 267, 428 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  â€œNeither the restricting of every lot within the area covered, nor absolute identity of restrictions upon different lots is essential to the existence of a neighborhood scheme.â€
Â Pitts v. Brown,  215 S.C. 122, 130, 54 S.E.2d 538, 542 (1949).Â  However, extensive omissions or variations tend to show that no scheme exists, and that the restrictions are only personal contracts.Â  Id.
In this case, testimony revealed some people did not submit plans or specifications for certain projects to the Association and that the Association inconsistently enforced this requirement.Â  Moreover, pictures of property throughout the neighborhood show the absence of any scheme with respect to fencing or other structures.Â  In fact, the Associationâ€™s current president testified the Associationâ€™s board was â€œfine with the fence,â€ and that Cromerâ€™s husband â€œcould have submitted a variance and it couldâ€™ve been approved by the board if he wouldâ€™ve been hospitable, but he took it on himself to do whatever.â€Â  Additionally, we defer to the masterâ€™s ability to observe the witnesses and emphasize that the master visited the Subdivision and was in the best position to determine the existence, if any, of a neighborhood scheme.Â  Accordingly, we hold a preponderance of the evidence supports the masterâ€™s conclusion that the Association waived its right to approve of plans and specifications with respect to Cromerâ€™s fence.
CONCLUSION
We hold the masterâ€™s ruling that the 1985 Regulations are invalid is the law of the case.Â  In addition, we find the 1965 Declaration does not prohibit the parking of Cromerâ€™s motor home and trailer on her property.Â  Consequently, we need not address the Associationâ€™s other contentions with respect to the motor home and affirm the masterâ€™s decision with respect to the surety bond.Â  
Regarding Cromerâ€™s fence, we hold a preponderance of the evidence supports the masterâ€™s conclusion that the Association waived its right to require approval.Â  As a result, we find the master did not abuse his discretion in denying the Associationâ€™s request for injunctive relief.Â  Based on the foregoing, the masterâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] This recorded deed corrected a prior quit claim deed which did not include the specific rights enumerated.Â  
[3] Fifteen days later, the Association adopted a second declaration which neither party uses to justify relief on appeal.Â

title: Gissel v. Hart
description: Appellants appeal from an order of the circuit court upholding arbitration awards.  Appellants argue the arbitrator exceeded his powers in entering awards against them in their individual capacities and that the awards constituted a manifest disregard of the law.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Case No. 2003-CP-10-02195
Kevin Gissel and Christina Gissel (formerly Christina
Eckley), Respondents,
v.
Charles Hart and Gene Hart, Appellants.
____________
Case No. 2003-CP-10-02703
Wade A. McEachern, Respondent,
v.
Charles Hart and Gene Hart, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4224
Heard March 7, 2007 â€“ Filed March 26, 2007

VACATED IN PART, AFFIRMED IN PART


  
    
      
Steven L. Smith, of Charleston, for Appellants.
Donald Higgins Howe and WalterÂ  Bilbro, Jr., both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.: Â Charles Hart and Gene Hart (the Harts) appeal from an order of the circuit court upholding arbitration awards in favor of Kevin and Christina Gissel (the Gissels) and Wade A. McEachern.Â  We vacate in part and affirm in part.
FACTS
In 2000, the Gissels purchased a mobile home for the stated cash price of $73,919.34 from Homes America, Inc.Â  Around the same time, McEachern purchased a mobile home for a stated cash price of $76,855.00 from Homes America.Â  The sales contracts for each of these two transactions listed Homes America as the â€œDEALERâ€ and were signed as â€œApprovedâ€ by Gene Hart.Â  The contracts each contained an identical Notice of Arbitration Provision.[1]Â  Homes America subsequently merged into Southern Showcase Housing, Inc.Â  
In 2003, the Gissels and McEachern initiated separate actions against â€œHomes America, Inc., Southern Showcase Housing, Inc., Charles Hart, Gene Hart and Amery English,â€ alleging claims for (1) negligence, (2) fraud, and (3) breach of contract with fraudulent intent.Â  The amended complaints asserted claims against â€œthe Defendants, jointly, severally and in the alternativeâ€ and sought â€œboth actual and punitive damages on each of the above causes of action in an amount to be determined by a jury, together with the cost of this action.â€Â  The complaints essentially asserted the mobile homes were improperly installed and contained a number of defects.Â  Â Â 
Southern Showcase Housing filed separate Motions to Dismiss against the Gissels and McEachern in August 2003.Â  In September 2003, the Harts also filed Motions to Dismiss separately against the Gissels and McEachern.Â  The motions filed by the Harts were virtually identical to those filed by Southern Showcase Housing and asserted the complaints should be dismissed with prejudice and the matters referred to arbitration under the Federal Arbitration Act (FAA)[2] â€œas required in the contract by and between the parties.â€Â  The same attorney represented both Southern Showcase Housing and the Harts.Â Â Â  
The circuit court construed the motions as being to stay litigation and compel arbitration.Â  The court issued two orders granting the motions, one with the Gissels as the plaintiffs, and the other with McEachern as the named plaintiff.Â  In each order, the court stated, â€œThis litigation is hereby stayed, and the parties are ordered to arbitrate this matter pursuant to the [FAA] . . . .â€Â  (Emphasis added.)Â  The captions in both orders identified the defendants Southern Showcase Housing, the Harts, and Amery English as parties.[3]  
At the arbitration hearing, the Harts made an appearance through counsel, who presented evidence on their behalf.Â  According to the Harts, â€œDefendants Homes America, Inc., Gene Hart and Charles Hart only offered one witness, David Bennett, administrator of the South Carolina Manufactured Housing Board. . . .Â  Basically, Mr. Bennett testified the damages alleged in the Plaintiffsâ€™ Amended Complaint were the financial responsibility of Defendant Homes America, Inc.â€Â  
During the course of the arbitration proceedings, Southern Showcase Housing settled with the Gissels and McEachern; however, the Harts were not included in the settlement and became the only remaining defendants.[4]Â Â Â  
The arbitrator thereafter issued decisions awarding both actual and punitive damages to the Gissels and McEachern.[5]Â  The arbitrator awarded the Gissels $55,000.00 in â€œactual, consequential and incidental damagesâ€ against the Harts â€œjointly and severally,â€ $45,000.00 in punitive damages against Charles Hart â€œindividually,â€ and $45,000.00 in punitive damages against Gene Hart â€œindividually.â€Â  In a separate ruling, the arbitrator awarded McEachern $53,000.00 in actual damages against the Harts â€œjointly and severally,â€ $45,000.00 in punitive damages against Charles Hart â€œindividually,â€ and $45,000.00 in punitive damages against Gene Hart â€œindividually.â€Â  
The Harts appealed to the circuit court, which upheld the arbitratorâ€™s awards.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Harts contend the decision of the arbitrator should be vacated because the arbitrator exceeded his powers in entering awards against them individually and his decision constituted a manifest disregard of the law.
â€œThe policy of the United States and South Carolina is to favor arbitration of disputes.â€[6]Â  â€œIn order to advance the underlying purposes of arbitration, the scope of judicial review is necessarily restricted.â€[7]Â  
Section 10(a) of the FAA provides that an arbitration award may be vacated[8] on four statutory grounds:

(1) where the award was procured by corruption, fraud, or undue means; 
(2) where there was evident partiality or corruption in the arbitrators, or either of them; 
(3) where the arbitrators were guilty of misconduct in refusing to postpone the hearing, upon sufficient cause shown, or in refusing to hear evidence pertinent and material to the controversy; or of any other misbehavior by which the rights of any party have been prejudiced; or 
(4) where the arbitrators exceeded their powers, or so imperfectly executed them that a mutual, final, and definite award upon the subject matter submitted was not made.[9]

The Harts acknowledge there was no fraud, partiality, or corruption in this case, but contend the arbitrator exceeded his powers.Â  â€œArbitrators exceed their
powers within the meaning of Â§ 10(a)(4) of the FAA where their award resolves an issue that is not
arbitrable because it is outside the scope of the arbitration agreement.â€[10]Â  
The Harts also contend the award constitutes a manifest disregard of the law.Â  â€œAn
arbitratorâ€™s award may be vacated where there has been a â€˜manifest disregard or perverse misconstruction of the
law.â€™ â€[11]Â  â€œHowever, this non-statutory ground requires something more than a mere error of
law, or failure on the part of the arbitrator to understand or apply the law.â€[12]Â  It presupposes something beyond a mere error in construing or applying the
law and even a clearly erroneous interpretation of the contract cannot be disturbed.[13]Â  
At the hearing before the circuit court, the Harts contended the arbitrator exceeded his powers by awarding damages against them â€œindividuallyâ€ and the awards constituted a manifest disregard of the law.Â  The Harts asserted the amended complaints stated that â€œat all times herein mentionedâ€ the Harts were â€œacting as agents, servants, and employees.â€[14]Â  They further asserted the complaints contained no factual allegations of any wrongdoing by them in their individual capacities.Â  The circuit court, in colloquy from the bench, noted that, â€œYouâ€™ve got to give some credence to the fact that they are named separately and that they are referred to collectively as defendants.â€Â  The circuit court ruled from the bench that the arbitratorâ€™s awards should be upheld, and subsequently issued a short form order summarily denying the motion to vacate the awards.Â  
On appeal, the Harts argue that the award of damages, both actual and punitive, against them should be vacated because they were not sued in their individual capacities.Â  The Harts assert:Â  â€œThe arbitratorâ€™s decision contains no specific findings of fact or conclusions of law.Â  It is therefore impossible to actually pinpoint the basis for his conclusion that each of the individuals named as Defendants in this case [is] Â liable for . . . actual damages and . . . punitive damages.Â  This decision is clearly beyond both the arbitratorâ€™s authority and power, and made with manifest disregard for the law.â€Â  
â€œThe character in which one is made a party to a suit must be determined from the allegations of the pleadings, and not from the title alone.â€[15]Â  â€œWhere the allegations of the complaint indicate with reasonable certainty that a plaintiff sues, or a defendant is sued, in a representative capacity, although not specifically stated, this is sufficient to fix the character of the suit.â€[16]Â  â€œWhere it is doubtful in what capacity a party sues or is sued, the entire complaint must be examined to determine the question, and reference may also be had to the pleadings as a whole or to the entire record.â€[17]Â Â Â

We agree with the Harts that the complaints did not clearly assert claims against them in their individual capacities.Â  The fact that they were listed as defendants in the captions of the complaints is not determinative of what capacity they were being sued in, and even the captions did not expressly state that they were each being sued in an individual, as opposed to representative, capacity.Â  In addition, the factual allegations in the body of the complaints specifically alleged the Harts were acting â€œat all timesâ€ as agents and employees of the defendant corporation, Homes America, Inc. Â None of the allegations stated the Harts committed any acts in their individual capacities or that relief was sought against them other than as agents and employees of the corporation.[21]Â  We note that an allegation of joint and several liability is a distinct concept that refers to the allocation of any damages award, not to whether the defendants are sued in a representative or individual capacity.[22]Â  Moreover, in the request for relief, the complaints essentially sought one recovery against all of the defendants on the various causes of action.[23]Â Â Â  
In this case, the contracts signed by the Gissels and McEachern were with Homes America (now Southern Showcase Housing).Â  The contracts were each in the name of the corporation Homes America, which was listed as â€œDEALER,â€ and signed â€œByâ€ Gene Hart as a signatory for the corporation.Â  Gene Hart was not listed as signing in an individual capacity on the contract.Â  Additionally, Customer Pre-Delivery and Set-Up Agreements were signed â€œBY MANAGERâ€ Gene Hart indicating he was signing on behalf of Homes America.Â  Charles Hart was not a signatory to any of the contracts.Â  Thus, there was no basis on which to predicate an award of individual liability.[24]Â  
Based on the foregoing, we vacate the portions of the arbitratorâ€™s awards that purport to impose liability â€œindividuallyâ€ on the Harts for punitive damages and, if the awards can be read to impose liability â€œindividuallyâ€ on the Harts for actual damages, for actual damages as well.  We affirm the awards, however, to the extent that they impose actual damages against the Harts in their representative capacities as agents, servants, and employees of Homes America, the capacities in which they were sued.

title: Marlar v. State
description: Marlar appeals the deniall of his application for post-conviction relief.  This court granted certiorari to review the denial.  Because the PCR court's order failed to make specific findings of fact as to each of the issues raised in the PCR application and because there was no evidence to support the finding that Marlar failed to present any evidence regarding the specific allegations in the application, we reverse the PCR court's order and remand the matter for specific findings.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Anthony Marlar, Petitioner
v.
State of South Carolina, Respondent
      
    
  


Appeal from Anderson County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4225
Heard September 14, 2006 â€“ Filed March 26, 2007

VACATED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Christopher L. Newton, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Anthony Marlar was convicted of first-degree burglary and first-degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  His petition for post-conviction relief (PCR) was denied.Â  This court granted certiorari to review the PCR courtâ€™s denial of relief.Â  We vacate and remand. 
FACTS
In the early morning hours of February 23, 1993, two men with stockings covering their faces broke into the victimâ€™s home.Â  The victimâ€™s three-year-old daughter was sleeping in the bed with her at the time.Â  The victim heard the short, stocky male tell the tall, slim male, â€œTony, get the girl out of here.â€Â  The tall, slim male replied, â€œOh, sh--,â€ when the name â€œTonyâ€ was used.Â  â€œTonyâ€ took the child out of the room and returned.Â  The short, stocky male asked â€œTony,â€ â€œIs this her?â€Â  After â€œTonyâ€ nodded his head in assent, the two men held a knife to victim and took turns raping her.Â  When they finished, they cleaned the victim and threatened her before leaving.Â  
The victim went to the hospital, and a rape kit was performed.Â  The victim told hospital personnel and police that both males ejaculated during the crime.Â  She told police that she believed the two males were brothers Bobby Marlar and Anthony â€œTonyâ€ Marlar, because of their build.Â  The Marlar brothers were in her house the prior week to help her roommate, whom Bobby Marlar was dating, move out of the house.Â  The victim did not recognize the voices of the perpetrators.Â  Although both Bobby and Tony Marlar were briefly interviewed, the criminal investigation did not progress for several years.Â  
In 1996, the investigation was reopened.Â  In March 1996, police questioned Jerry Fields, who denied participating in the crime and indicated that he was with Tony Marlar (â€œMarlarâ€) that evening.Â  After DNA collected from the victim matched Fields, he eventually confessed and implicated Marlar as the second suspect.Â  Fields agreed to plead guilty and to testify at Marlarâ€™s trial in exchange for a twenty-year sentence.Â  There was no DNA evidence linking Marlar to the crime, and two pubic hairs found in the bed did not match Fields, the victim, the victimâ€™s boyfriend, or Marlar. Â Prior to the DNA results linking Fields, Marlar was questioned by police and he stated he could not recall where he was three years earlier on the night of the crime.Â  Marlar also denied any involvement in the crime and indicated that he probably was with Fields that night.Â Â Â  
At trial, the victim testified that she was absolutely sure that the tall, slim rapist was Marlar because:Â  (1) of his build; (2) Fields referred to the second rapist as â€œTony;â€ and (3) the second rapist was familiar with her house and knew the telephone in her bedroom did not work.Â  Unlike her initial statement, the victim testified at trial that the second rapist did not ejaculate, explaining the lack of DNA evidence linking Marlar.Â  Fields testified that he had also been in the victimâ€™s house, when the victim was not there, to help Bobby Marlar move out his girlfriend prior to the rape.Â  Fields stated that he and Marlar raped the victim, and he denied having any disagreement with Marlar or any other motivation to testify against him.Â  Marlar did not testify and no evidence was presented in his defense.Â  He was convicted and sentenced to a total of forty-four years.Â  
Marlar filed an application for PCR.Â  In his application, Marlar insinuated that Fields and Fieldsâ€™ brother, â€œTerry,â€ who were both in prison for burglaries they committed together, were the actual rapists.Â  He alleged counsel was ineffective for, among other reasons, failing to cross-examine Fields about his motivation to implicate Marlar because Marlar swore out a warrant against Fields in 1994 for damaging Marlarâ€™s truck.Â  Marlar also alleged that counsel was ineffective for failing to present the exculpatory hair evidence and in not allowing him to testify in his own defense.Â  
Counsel testified at the PCR hearing that he did not recall whether Marlar informed him about the warrant taken out against Fields.Â  Counsel stated he did not think Marlar would hold up well on cross-examination by the State.Â  Counsel also stated that he did not subpoena the SLED agent who examined the pubic hairs or present the pubic hair evidence because there was no other DNA evidence linking Marlar to the crime, and he did not want to present any evidence because he did not want to lose the right to last closing argument.Â  Counsel stated that he did not think having the SLED agent to testify regarding the pubic hairs would change anything.Â  The SLED agent who tested the pubic hairs stated at the PCR hearing that if he had been called to testify at the trial, he would have testified that the hairs did not match Marlar, Fields, the victim, or the victimâ€™s boyfriend.Â  Finally, Marlar testified that counsel never discussed the pubic hairs with him, counsel merely informed him that the DNA evidence did not match.Â  Marlar also stated counsel told him not to testify, despite Marlarâ€™s desire to do so, because he would lose the last argument.Â  
After a hearing, the PCR court denied relief and dismissed the petition.Â  The court found counsel rendered â€œreasonably effective assistance under the prevailing professional norms and demonstrated a normal degree of skill, knowledge and professional judgment that is expected of an attorney who practices criminal law.â€Â  As to the specific issues raised in the PCR application, the court held:Â  â€œAs to any allegations raised in the application or at the hearing not specifically addressed by this Order, this Court finds that the applicant failed to present any evidence regarding such allegations.Â  Accordingly, this Court finds that the applicant failed to meet his burden of proof regarding them.â€Â  This petition for certiorari followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThis Court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law.â€Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C. 365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005).Â  A PCR courtâ€™s findings will be upheld on appeal if there is â€œany evidence of probative value sufficient to support them.â€Â  Id.Â  The appellate court must reverse where there is no probative evidence to support the findings.Â  Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 144, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Marlar argues the PCR courtâ€™s order was inadequate and should be remanded for specific findings of fact.Â  We agree.
A PCR court â€œshall make specific findings of fact, and state expressly its conclusions of law, relating to each issue presented.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-80 (2003).Â  PCR courts have been repeatedly admonished regarding the failure to specifically rule on the issues presented in a PCR application.Â  See Bryson v. State, 328 S.C. 236, 236-37, 493 S.E.2d 500, 500 (1997) (vacating a PCR order and remanding the matter for specific findings of fact and conclusions of law); McCullough v. State, 320 S.C. 270, 272, 464 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1995); Pruitt v. State, 310 S.C. 254, 255, 423 S.E.2d 127, 128 (1992) (vacating and remanding PCR order dismissing the action where the PCR court failed to address the issues raised in the application); see also Garner v. State, 371 S.C. 1, 1, 626 S.E.2d 860, 860 (2006) (emphasizing language in section 17-27-80 that specific findings of fact and conclusions of law regarding each issue presented must be made by the PCR court).Â  Â 
Citing Humbert v. State, 345 S.C. 332, 548 S.E.2d 862 (2001), the State argues that any complaint regarding the sufficiency of the order is not preserved for review because Marlar did not file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion requesting the PCR court to specifically address each issue raised in the application.Â  In the past, our state supreme court has overlooked the failure to file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion in order to attend to the pervasive problem of inadequate orders.Â  McCullough, 320 S.C. at 272, 464 S.E.2d at 341 (remanding matter to PCR court, despite the fact that no Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion had been filed, and admonishing all those involved to carefully prepare and review PCR orders to ensure they specifically address the issues raised and make conclusions of law); Pruitt, 310 S.C. at 255, 423 S.E.2d at 128 (vacating and remanding the PCR courtâ€™s order, despite the fact that no Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion was filed, to address the failure of many PCR orders to address all the issues raised).Â  In the more recent case of Humbert, the court did not overlook the failure to file a Rule 59(e) motion to preserve one issue not specifically addressed in the PCR order.Â  Humbert, 345 S.C. at 337, 548 S.E.2d at 865 (finding that, although the PCR court addressed the issue of whether it was ineffective assistance of counsel to allow the petitioner to wear the jail jumpsuit during his trial, the issue of whether it was ineffective assistance for trial counsel to allow petitioner to proceed to trial wearing shackles and a jail identification bracelet was not preserved because the PCR courtâ€™s order did not address it and no Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion was filed).Â  It does not appear that Humbert overruled the prior cases, and it is not clear whether, in light of Humbert, an appellate court may still take the extraordinary action of overlooking the failure to file a Rule 59(e) motion and remanding matters so that specific orders may be issued by the PCR court.Â  What is clear, however, is that the problem of PCR orders that do not address each issue raised by an applicant continues to permeate our judicial system.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
In any event, we do not believe that we need to take any extraordinary action in this case because we believe the issue is preserved.Â  The PCR courtâ€™s order specifically acknowledged that some issues were not addressed.Â  The court made the finding that, as to those issues, no evidence was presented.Â  When, as here, the PCR courtâ€™s order specifically addresses its failure to delineate each issue and gives reasons for the ruling, the issue has been finally ruled upon by the lower court and is preserved for appeal.Â  
As to the merits of the PCR courtâ€™s ruling, Marlar presented evidence to support his claims.Â  Accordingly, there is no evidence to support the PCR courtâ€™s finding that he failed to present any evidence.Â  We must vacate the order and remand the matter for a new PCR hearing.Â  We caution the PCR court on remand to make specific findings of fact and conclusions of law as to each issue raised in Marlarâ€™s PCR application.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons outlined above, the PCR courtâ€™s decision denying relief is 
VACATED and REMANDED for a new hearing.
 HEARN, C.J., and SHORT, J., concur.Â

title: Patricia Grand Hotel v. MacGuire Enterprises
description: In this lease dispute, MacGuire Enterprises, operator of a restaurant in leased space within the Patricia Grand Hotel,appeals the trial court's order "Ending Action and Amending Lease."  MacGuire argues the trial court erred in: (1) ruling the parties' agreement not to compete in food and beverage services applied only to the restaurant property, not to the entire hotel; and (2) failing to find there was not an agreement as to the sale of food and beverages within the hotel.   We affirm the trial court's finding that the agreement not to compete only applied to the demised area of the restuarant, lounge, and pool bar area.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Patricia Grand Hotel, LLC, Respondent,
v.
MacGuire Enterprises, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4226
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 26, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John M. Leiter, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Douglas M. Zayicek, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  MacGuire Enterprises (â€œMacGuireâ€), operator of the restaurant, â€œChantillyâ€™s,â€ within the Patricia Grand Hotel, appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s order, â€œEnding Action & Amending Lease.â€Â  MacGuire argues that the trial court erred in:Â  (1) ruling the partiesâ€™ agreement not to compete in food and beverage services applied only to the restaurant property, not to the entire hotel; and (2) failing to find there was not an agreement as to the sale of food and beverages within the hotel.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Patricia Grand Hotel, LLC, (â€œPatricia Grandâ€), owns and operates the oceanfront Patricia Grand Hotel (the â€œhotelâ€) in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.Â  In September of 1994, the lease to the space housing the restaurant, Chantillyâ€™s, and the attached lounge was assigned from Huffman Investments, Inc., to MacGuire.[2]Â  The lease assigned to and signed by MacGuire stated that MacGuire would provide services within the â€œdemised property,â€ which included:Â  a 140-seat restaurant located within the hotel; a kitchen area with equipment; and an attached lounge area.Â Â  
MacGuire began operating Chantillyâ€™s and the lounge area according to the lease agreement.Â  At some point, MacGuire also began operating a pool bar at the hotelâ€™s pool during the summer months.Â  The pool bar area was not attached to Chantillyâ€™s or the lounge.Â  Patricia Grand believed operation of the pool bar was not part of the lease, and MacGuire believed that the pool bar was included in the lease because its predecessor in interest also operated the pool bar. Â The parties could not resolve the dispute, and on October 23, 2003, Patricia Grand filed both an eviction action in magistrate court to evict MacGuire from the pool bar and an action for civil damages in circuit court under the theories of trespass, breach of contract, quantum meruit, conversion, and injunction.Â  MacGuireâ€™s motion to have the eviction action transferred from the magistrate court to the circuit was granted, and the eviction action and the damages action were consolidated.Â  Â Â 
Prior to the jury trial, the parties informed the circuit court that they had reached a settlement agreement wherein the lease would be amended to reflect that it â€œincludes the pool bar under the demise [sic] premises,â€ that the rent would increase to $3,300, and that MacGuire could increase some prices on golf and meal packages. Â MacGuireâ€™s attorney then informed the circuit court that â€œ[t]here are a number of outstanding issues, your honor, that constitute the atmospherics between the parties and thatâ€™s what made discussions up to this point difficult,â€ but that the parties had quickly agreed on the main issue.Â  MacGuireâ€™s attorney noted that the parties had â€œagreed to cooperate in good faith on the number of issues that are still remaining,â€ and he pointed out that Patricia Grand was operating an Icee machine near the pool bar.Â  Patricia Grand agreed that the Icee operation would cease.Â  The agreement was put on the record and the court approved it.Â  Further, the court ordered the parties to put the agreement in writing and have it signed by all the parties.Â
